in proud Italy,\r","Whose manners still our tardy apish nation\r","Limps after in base imitation.\r","Where doth the world thrust forth a vanity--\r","So it be new, there's no respect how vile--\r","That is not quickly buzzed into his ears?\r","Then all too late comes counsel to be heard,\r","Where will doth mutiny with wit's regard.\r","Direct not him whose way himself will choose:\r","'Tis breath thou lack'st, and that breath wilt thou lose.\r","\r","JOHN OF GAUNT:\r","Methinks I am a prophet new inspired\r","And thus expiring do foretell of him:\r","His rash fierce blaze of riot cannot last,\r","For violent fires soon burn out themselves;\r","Small showers last long, but sudden storms are short;\r","He tires betimes that spurs too fast betimes;\r","With eager feeding food doth choke the feeder:\r","Light vanity, insatiate cormorant,\r","Consuming means, soon preys upon itself.\r","This royal throne of kings, this scepter'd isle,\r","This earth of majesty, this seat of Mars,\r","This other Eden, demi-paradise,\r","This fortress built by Nature for herself\r","Against infection and the hand of war,\r","This happy breed of men, this little world,\r","This precious stone set in the silver sea,\r","Which serves it in the office of a wall,\r","Or as a moat defensive to a house,\r","Against the envy of less happier lands,\r","This blessed plot, this earth, this realm, this England,\r","This nurse, this teeming womb of royal kings,\r","Fear'd by their breed and famous by their birth,\r","Renowned for their deeds as far from home,\r","For Christian service and true chivalry,\r","As is the sepulchre in stubborn Jewry,\r","Of the world's ransom, blessed Mary's Son,\r","This land of such dear souls, this dear dear land,\r","Dear for her reputation through the world,\r","Is now leased out, I die pronouncing it,\r","Like to a tenement or pelting farm:\r","England, bound in with the triumphant sea\r","Whose rocky shore beats back the envious siege\r","Of watery Neptune, is now bound in with shame,\r","With inky blots and rotten parchment bonds:\r","That England, that was wont to conquer others,\r","Hath made a shameful conquest of itself.\r","Ah, would the scandal vanish with my life,\r","How happy then were my ensuing death!\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","The king is come: deal mildly with his youth;\r","For young hot colts being raged do rage the more.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","How fares our noble uncle, Lancaster?\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","What comfort, man? how is't with aged Gaunt?\r","\r","JOHN OF GAUNT:\r","O how that name befits my composition!\r","Old Gaunt indeed, and gaunt in being old:\r","Within me grief hath kept a tedious fast;\r","And who abstains from meat that is not gaunt?\r","For sleeping England long time have I watch'd;\r","Watching breeds leanness, leanness is all gaunt:\r","The pleasure that some fathers feed upon,\r","Is my strict fast; I mean, my children's looks;\r","And therein fasting, hast thou made me gaunt:\r","Gaunt am I for the grave, gaunt as a grave,\r","Whose hollow womb inherits nought but bones.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Can sick men play so nicely with their names?\r","\r","JOHN OF GAUNT:\r","No, misery makes sport to mock itself:\r","Since thou dost seek to kill my name in me,\r","I mock my name, great king, to flatter thee.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Should dying men flatter with those that live?\r","\r","JOHN OF GAUNT:\r","No, no, men living flatter those that die.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Thou, now a-dying, say'st thou flatterest me.\r","\r","JOHN OF GAUNT:\r","O, no! thou diest, though I the sicker be.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","I am in health, I breathe, and see thee ill.\r","\r","JOHN OF GAUNT:\r","Now He that made me knows I see thee ill;\r","Ill in myself to see, and in thee seeing ill.\r","Thy death-bed is no lesser than thy land\r","Wherein thou liest in reputation sick;\r","And thou, too careless patient as thou art,\r","Commit'st thy anointed body to the cure\r","Of those physicians that first wounded thee:\r","A thousand flatterers sit within thy crown,\r","Whose compass is no bigger than thy head;\r","And yet, incaged in so small a verge,\r","The waste is no whit lesser than thy land.\r","O, had thy grandsire with a prophet's eye\r","Seen how his son's son should destroy his sons,\r","From forth thy reach he would have laid thy shame,\r","Deposing thee before thou wert possess'd,\r","Which art possess'd now to depose thyself.\r","Why, cousin, wert thou regent of the world,\r","It were a shame to let this land by lease;\r","But for thy world enjoying but this land,\r","Is it not more than shame to shame it so?\r","Landlord of England art thou now, not king:\r","Thy state of law is bondslave to the law; And thou--\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","A lunatic lean-witted fool,\r","Presuming on an ague's privilege,\r","Darest with thy frozen admonition\r","Make pale our cheek, chasing the royal blood\r","With fury from his native residence.\r","Now, by my seat's right royal majesty,\r","Wert thou not brother to great Edward's son,\r","This tongue that runs so roundly in thy head\r","Should run thy head from thy unreverent shoulders.\r","\r","JOHN OF GAUNT:\r","O, spare me not, my brother Edward's son,\r","For that I was his father Edward's son;\r","That blood already, like the pelican,\r","Hast thou tapp'd out and drunkenly caroused:\r","My brother Gloucester, plain well-meaning soul,\r","Whom fair befal in heaven 'mongst happy souls!\r","May be a precedent and witness good\r","That thou respect'st not spilling Edward's blood:\r","Join with the present sickness that I have;\r","And thy unkindness be like crooked age,\r","To crop at once a too long wither'd flower.\r","Live in thy shame, but die not shame with thee!\r","These words hereafter thy tormentors be!\r","Convey me to my bed, then to my grave:\r","Love they to live that love and honour have.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","And let them die that age and sullens have;\r","For both hast thou, and both become the grave.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","I do beseech your majesty, impute his words\r","To wayward sickliness and age in him:\r","He loves you, on my life, and holds you dear\r","As Harry Duke of Hereford, were he here.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Right, you say true: as Hereford's love, so his;\r","As theirs, so mine; and all be as it is.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","My liege, old Gaunt commends him to your majesty.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","What says he?\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","Nay, nothing; all is said\r","His tongue is now a stringless instrument;\r","Words, life and all, old Lancaster hath spent.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Be York the next that must be bankrupt so!\r","Though death be poor, it ends a mortal woe.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","The ripest fruit first falls, and so doth he;\r","His time is spent, our pilgrimage must be.\r","So much for that. Now for our Irish wars:\r","We must supplant those rough rug-headed kerns,\r","Which live like venom where no venom else\r","But only they have privilege to live.\r","And for these great affairs do ask some charge,\r","Towards our assistance we do seize to us\r","The plate, corn, revenues and moveables,\r","Whereof our uncle Gaunt did stand possess'd.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","How long shall I be patient? ah, how long\r","Shall tender duty make me suffer wrong?\r","Not Gloucester's death, nor Hereford's banishment\r","Not Gaunt's rebukes, nor England's private wrongs,\r","Nor the prevention of poor Bolingbroke\r","About his marriage, nor my own disgrace,\r","Have ever made me sour my patient cheek,\r","Or bend one wrinkle on my sovereign's face.\r","I am the last of noble Edward's sons,\r","Of whom thy father, Prince of Wales, was first:\r","In war was never lion raged more fierce,\r","In peace was never gentle lamb more mild,\r","Than was that young and princely gentleman.\r","His face thou hast, for even so look'd he,\r","Accomplish'd with the number of thy hours;\r","But when he frown'd, it was against the French\r","And not against his friends; his noble hand\r","Did will what he did spend and spent not that\r","Which his triumphant father's hand had won;\r","His hands were guilty of no kindred blood,\r","But bloody with the enemies of his kin.\r","O Richard! York is too far gone with grief,\r","Or else he never would compare between.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Why, uncle, what's the matter?\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","O my liege,\r","Pardon me, if you please; if not, I, pleased\r","Not to be pardon'd, am content withal.\r","Seek you to seize and gripe into your hands\r","The royalties and rights of banish'd Hereford?\r","Is not Gaunt dead, and doth not Hereford live?\r","Was not Gaunt just, and is not Harry true?\r","Did not the one deserve to have an heir?\r","Is not his heir a well-deserving son?\r","Take Hereford's rights away, and take from Time\r","His charters and his customary rights;\r","Let not to-morrow then ensue to-day;\r","Be not thyself; for how art thou a king\r","But by fair sequence and succession?\r","Now, afore God--God forbid I say true!--\r","If you do wrongfully seize Hereford's rights,\r","Call in the letters patent that he hath\r","By his attorneys-general to sue\r","His livery, and deny his offer'd homage,\r","You pluck a thousand dangers on your head,\r","You lose a thousand well-disposed hearts\r","And prick my tender patience, to those thoughts\r","Which honour and allegiance cannot think.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Think what you will, we seize into our hands\r","His plate, his goods, his money and his lands.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","I'll not be by the while: my liege, farewell:\r","What will ensue hereof, there's none can tell;\r","But by bad courses may be understood\r","That their events can never fall out good.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Go, Bushy, to the Earl of Wiltshire straight:\r","Bid him repair to us to Ely House\r","To see this business. To-morrow next\r","We will for Ireland; and 'tis time, I trow:\r","And we create, in absence of ourself,\r","Our uncle York lord governor of England;\r","For he is just and always loved us well.\r","Come on, our queen: to-morrow must we part;\r","Be merry, for our time of stay is short\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","Well, lords, the Duke of Lancaster is dead.\r","\r","LORD ROSS:\r","And living too; for now his son is duke.\r","\r","LORD WILLOUGHBY:\r","Barely in title, not in revenue.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","Richly in both, if justice had her right.\r","\r","LORD ROSS:\r","My heart is great; but it must break with silence,\r","Ere't be disburden'd with a liberal tongue.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","Nay, speak thy mind; and let him ne'er speak more\r","That speaks thy words again to do thee harm!\r","\r","LORD WILLOUGHBY:\r","Tends that thou wouldst speak to the Duke of Hereford?\r","If it be so, out with it boldly, man;\r","Quick is mine ear to hear of good towards him.\r","\r","LORD ROSS:\r","No good at all that I can do for him;\r","Unless you call it good to pity him,\r","Bereft and gelded of his patrimony.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","Now, afore God, 'tis shame such wrongs are borne\r","In him, a royal prince, and many moe\r","Of noble blood in this declining land.\r","The king is not himself, but basely led\r","By flatterers; and what they will inform,\r","Merely in hate, 'gainst any of us all,\r","That will the king severely prosecute\r","'Gainst us, our lives, our children, and our heirs.\r","\r","LORD ROSS:\r","The commons hath he pill'd with grievous taxes,\r","And quite lost their hearts: the nobles hath he fined\r","For ancient quarrels, and quite lost their hearts.\r","\r","LORD WILLOUGHBY:\r","And daily new exactions are devised,\r","As blanks, benevolences, and I wot not what:\r","But what, o' God's name, doth become of this?\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","Wars have not wasted it, for warr'd he hath not,\r","But basely yielded upon compromise\r","That which his noble ancestors achieved with blows:\r","More hath he spent in peace than they in wars.\r","\r","LORD ROSS:\r","The Earl of Wiltshire hath the realm in farm.\r","\r","LORD WILLOUGHBY:\r","The king's grown bankrupt, like a broken man.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","Reproach and dissolution hangeth over him.\r","\r","LORD ROSS:\r","He hath not money for these Irish wars,\r","His burthenous taxations notwithstanding,\r","But by the robbing of the banish'd duke.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","His noble kinsman: most degenerate king!\r","But, lords, we hear this fearful tempest sing,\r","Yet see no shelter to avoid the storm;\r","We see the wind sit sore upon our sails,\r","And yet we strike not, but securely perish.\r","\r","LORD ROSS:\r","We see the very wreck that we must suffer;\r","And unavoided is the danger now,\r","For suffering so the causes of our wreck.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","Not so; even through the hollow eyes of death\r","I spy life peering; but I dare not say\r","How near the tidings of our comfort is.\r","\r","LORD WILLOUGHBY:\r","Nay, let us share thy thoughts, as thou dost ours.\r","\r","LORD ROSS:\r","Be confident to speak, Northumberland:\r","We three are but thyself; and, speaking so,\r","Thy words are but as thoughts; therefore, be bold.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","Then thus: I have from Port le Blanc, a bay\r","In Brittany, received intelligence\r","That Harry Duke of Hereford, Rainold Lord Cobham,\r","That late broke from the Duke of Exeter,\r","His brother, Archbishop late of Canterbury,\r","Sir Thomas Erpingham, Sir John Ramston,\r","Sir John Norbery, Sir Robert Waterton and Francis Quoint,\r","All these well furnish'd by the Duke of Bretagne\r","With eight tall ships, three thousand men of war,\r","Are making hither with all due expedience\r","And shortly mean to touch our northern shore:\r","Perhaps they had ere this, but that they stay\r","The first departing of the king for Ireland.\r","If then we shall shake off our slavish yoke,\r","Imp out our drooping country's broken wing,\r","Redeem from broking pawn the blemish'd crown,\r","Wipe off the dust that hides our sceptre's gilt\r","And make high majesty look like itself,\r","Away with me in post to Ravenspurgh;\r","But if you faint, as fearing to do so,\r","Stay and be secret, and myself will go.\r","\r","LORD ROSS:\r","To horse, to horse! urge doubts to them that fear.\r","\r","LORD WILLOUGHBY:\r","Hold out my horse, and I will first be there.\r","\r","BUSHY:\r","Madam, your majesty is too much sad:\r","You promised, when you parted with the king,\r","To lay aside life-harming heaviness\r","And entertain a cheerful disposition.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","To please the king I did; to please myself\r","I cannot do it; yet I know no cause\r","Why I should welcome such a guest as grief,\r","Save bidding farewell to so sweet a guest\r","As my sweet Richard: yet again, methinks,\r","Some unborn sorrow, ripe in fortune's womb,\r","Is coming towards me, and my inward soul\r","With nothing trembles: at some thing it grieves,\r","More than with parting from my lord the king.\r","\r","BUSHY:\r","Each substance of a grief hath twenty shadows,\r","Which shows like grief itself, but is not so;\r","For sorrow's eye, glazed with blinding tears,\r","Divides one thing entire to many objects;\r","Like perspectives, which rightly gazed upon\r","Show nothing but confusion, eyed awry\r","Distinguish form: so your sweet majesty,\r","Looking awry upon your lord's departure,\r","Find shapes of grief, more than himself, to wail;\r","Which, look'd on as it is, is nought but shadows\r","Of what it is not. Then, thrice-gracious queen,\r","More than your lord's departure weep not: more's not seen;\r","Or if it be, 'tis with false sorrow's eye,\r","Which for things true weeps things imaginary.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","It may be so; but yet my inward soul\r","Persuades me it is otherwise: howe'er it be,\r","I cannot but be sad; so heavy sad\r","As, though on thinking on no thought I think,\r","Makes me with heavy nothing faint and shrink.\r","\r","BUSHY:\r","'Tis nothing but conceit, my gracious lady.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","'Tis nothing less: conceit is still derived\r","From some forefather grief; mine is not so,\r","For nothing had begot my something grief;\r","Or something hath the nothing that I grieve:\r","'Tis in reversion that I do possess;\r","But what it is, that is not yet known; what\r","I cannot name; 'tis nameless woe, I wot.\r","\r","GREEN:\r","God save your majesty! and well met, gentlemen:\r","I hope the king is not yet shipp'd for Ireland.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","Why hopest thou so? 'tis better hope he is;\r","For his designs crave haste, his haste good hope:\r","Then wherefore dost thou hope he is not shipp'd?\r","\r","GREEN:\r","That he, our hope, might have retired his power,\r","And driven into despair an enemy's hope,\r","Who strongly hath set footing in this land:\r","The banish'd Bolingbroke repeals himself,\r","And with uplifted arms is safe arrived\r","At Ravenspurgh.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","Now God in heaven forbid!\r","\r","GREEN:\r","Ah, madam, 'tis too true: and that is worse,\r","The Lord Northumberland, his son young Henry Percy,\r","The Lords of Ross, Beaumond, and Willoughby,\r","With all their powerful friends, are fled to him.\r","\r","BUSHY:\r","Why have you not proclaim'd Northumberland\r","And all the rest revolted faction traitors?\r","\r","GREEN:\r","We have: whereupon the Earl of Worcester\r","Hath broke his staff, resign'd his stewardship,\r","And all the household servants fled with him\r","To Bolingbroke.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","So, Green, thou art the midwife to my woe,\r","And Bolingbroke my sorrow's dismal heir:\r","Now hath my soul brought forth her prodigy,\r","And I, a gasping new-deliver'd mother,\r","Have woe to woe, sorrow to sorrow join'd.\r","\r","BUSHY:\r","Despair not, madam.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","Who shall hinder me?\r","I will despair, and be at enmity\r","With cozening hope: he is a flatterer,\r","A parasite, a keeper back of death,\r","Who gently would dissolve the bands of life,\r","Which false hope lingers in extremity.\r","\r","GREEN:\r","Here comes the Duke of York.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","With signs of war about his aged neck:\r","O, full of careful business are his looks!\r","Uncle, for God's sake, speak comfortable words.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Should I do so, I should belie my thoughts:\r","Comfort's in heaven; and we are on the earth,\r","Where nothing lives but crosses, cares and grief.\r","Your husband, he is gone to save far off,\r","Whilst others come to make him lose at home:\r","Here am I left to underprop his land,\r","Who, weak with age, cannot support myself:\r","Now comes the sick hour that his surfeit made;\r","Now shall he try his friends that flatter'd him.\r","\r","Servant:\r","My lord, your son was gone before I came.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","He was? Why, so! go all which way it will!\r","The nobles they are fled, the commons they are cold,\r","And will, I fear, revolt on Hereford's side.\r","Sirrah, get thee to Plashy, to my sister Gloucester;\r","Bid her send me presently a thousand pound:\r","Hold, take my ring.\r","\r","Servant:\r","My lord, I had forgot to tell your lordship,\r","To-day, as I came by, I called there;\r","But I shall grieve you to report the rest.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","What is't, knave?\r","\r","Servant:\r","An hour before I came, the duchess died.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","God for his mercy! what a tide of woes\r","Comes rushing on this woeful land at once!\r","I know not what to do: I would to God,\r","So my untruth had not provoked him to it,\r","The king had cut off my head with my brother's.\r","What, are there no posts dispatch'd for Ireland?\r","How shall we do for money for these wars?\r","Come, sister,--cousin, I would say--pray, pardon me.\r","Go, fellow, get thee home, provide some carts\r","And bring away the armour that is there.\r","Gentlemen, will you go muster men?\r","If I know how or which way to order these affairs\r","Thus thrust disorderly into my hands,\r","Never believe me. Both are my kinsmen:\r","The one is my sovereign, whom both my oath\r","And duty bids defend; the other again\r","Is my kinsman, whom the king hath wrong'd,\r","Whom conscience and my kindred bids to right.\r","Well, somewhat we must do. Come, cousin, I'll\r","Dispose of you.\r","Gentlemen, go, muster up your men,\r","And meet me presently at Berkeley.\r","I should to Plashy too;\r","But time will not permit: all is uneven,\r","And every thing is left at six and seven.\r","\r","BUSHY:\r","The wind sits fair for news to go to Ireland,\r","But none returns. For us to levy power\r","Proportionable to the enemy\r","Is all unpossible.\r","\r","GREEN:\r","Besides, our nearness to the king in love\r","Is near the hate of those love not the king.\r","\r","BAGOT:\r","And that's the wavering commons: for their love\r","Lies in their purses, and whoso empties them\r","By so much fills their hearts with deadly hate.\r","\r","BUSHY:\r","Wherein the king stands generally condemn'd.\r","\r","BAGOT:\r","If judgement lie in them, then so do we,\r","Because we ever have been near the king.\r","\r","GREEN:\r","Well, I will for refuge straight to Bristol castle:\r","The Earl of Wiltshire is already there.\r","\r","BUSHY:\r","Thither will I with you; for little office\r","The hateful commons will perform for us,\r","Except like curs to tear us all to pieces.\r","Will you go along with us?\r","\r","BAGOT:\r","No; I will to Ireland to his majesty.\r","Farewell: if heart's presages be not vain,\r","We three here art that ne'er shall meet again.\r","\r","BUSHY:\r","That's as York thrives to beat back Bolingbroke.\r","\r","GREEN:\r","Alas, poor duke! the task he undertakes\r","Is numbering sands and drinking oceans dry:\r","Where one on his side fights, thousands will fly.\r","Farewell at once, for once, for all, and ever.\r","\r","BUSHY:\r","Well, we may meet again.\r","\r","BAGOT:\r","I fear me, never.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","How far is it, my lord, to Berkeley now?\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","Believe me, noble lord,\r","I am a stranger here in Gloucestershire:\r","These high wild hills and rough uneven ways\r","Draws out our miles, and makes them wearisome,\r","And yet your fair discourse hath been as sugar,\r","Making the hard way sweet and delectable.\r","But I bethink me what a weary way\r","From Ravenspurgh to Cotswold will be found\r","In Ross and Willoughby, wanting your company,\r","Which, I protest, hath very much beguiled\r","The tediousness and process of my travel:\r","But theirs is sweetened with the hope to have\r","The present benefit which I possess;\r","And hope to joy is little less in joy\r","Than hope enjoy'd: by this the weary lords\r","Shall make their way seem short, as mine hath done\r","By sight of what I have, your noble company.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Of much less value is my company\r","Than your good words. But who comes here?\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","It is my son, young Harry Percy,\r","Sent from my brother Worcester, whencesoever.\r","Harry, how fares your uncle?\r","\r","HENRY PERCY:\r","I had thought, my lord, to have learn'd his health of you.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","Why, is he not with the queen?\r","\r","HENRY PERCY:\r","No, my good Lord; he hath forsook the court,\r","Broken his staff of office and dispersed\r","The household of the king.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","What was his reason?\r","He was not so resolved when last we spake together.\r","\r","HENRY PERCY:\r","Because your lordship was proclaimed traitor.\r","But he, my lord, is gone to Ravenspurgh,\r","To offer service to the Duke of Hereford,\r","And sent me over by Berkeley, to discover\r","What power the Duke of York had levied there;\r","Then with directions to repair to Ravenspurgh.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","Have you forgot the Duke of Hereford, boy?\r","\r","HENRY PERCY:\r","No, my good lord, for that is not forgot\r","Which ne'er I did remember: to my knowledge,\r","I never in my life did look on him.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","Then learn to know him now; this is the duke.\r","\r","HENRY PERCY:\r","My gracious lord, I tender you my service,\r","Such as it is, being tender, raw and young:\r","Which elder days shall ripen and confirm\r","To more approved service and desert.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","I thank thee, gentle Percy; and be sure\r","I count myself in nothing else so happy\r","As in a soul remembering my good friends;\r","And, as my fortune ripens with thy love,\r","It shall be still thy true love's recompense:\r","My heart this covenant makes, my hand thus seals it.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","How far is it to Berkeley? and what stir\r","Keeps good old York there with his men of war?\r","\r","HENRY PERCY:\r","There stands the castle, by yon tuft of trees,\r","Mann'd with three hundred men, as I have heard;\r","And in it are the Lords of York, Berkeley, and Seymour;\r","None else of name and noble estimate.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","Here come the Lords of Ross and Willoughby,\r","Bloody with spurring, fiery-red with haste.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Welcome, my lords. I wot your love pursues\r","A banish'd traitor: all my treasury\r","Is yet but unfelt thanks, which more enrich'd\r","Shall be your love and labour's recompense.\r","\r","LORD ROSS:\r","Your presence makes us rich, most noble lord.\r","\r","LORD WILLOUGHBY:\r","And far surmounts our labour to attain it.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Evermore thanks, the exchequer of the poor;\r","Which, till my infant fortune comes to years,\r","Stands for my bounty. But who comes here?\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","It is my Lord of Berkeley, as I guess.\r","\r","LORD BERKELEY:\r","My Lord of Hereford, my message is to you.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","My lord, my answer is--to Lancaster;\r","And I am come to seek that name in England;\r","And I must find that title in your tongue,\r","Before I make reply to aught you say.\r","\r","LORD BERKELEY:\r","Mistake me not, my lord; 'tis not my meaning\r","To raze one title of your honour out:\r","To you, my lord, I come, what lord you will,\r","From the most gracious regent of this land,\r","The Duke of York, to know what pricks you on\r","To take advantage of the absent time\r","And fright our native peace with self-born arms.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","I shall not need transport my words by you;\r","Here comes his grace in person. My noble uncle!\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Show me thy humble heart, and not thy knee,\r","Whose duty is deceiveable and false.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","My gracious uncle--\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Tut, tut!\r","Grace me no grace, nor uncle me no uncle:\r","I am no traitor's uncle; and that word 'grace.'\r","In an ungracious mouth is but profane.\r","Why have those banish'd and forbidden legs\r","Dared once to touch a dust of England's ground?\r","But then more 'why?' why have they dared to march\r","So many miles upon her peaceful bosom,\r","Frighting her pale-faced villages with war\r","And ostentation of despised arms?\r","Comest thou because the anointed king is hence?\r","Why, foolish boy, the king is left behind,\r","And in my loyal bosom lies his power.\r","Were I but now the lord of such hot youth\r","As when brave Gaunt, thy father, and myself\r","Rescued the Black Prince, that young Mars of men,\r","From forth the ranks of many thousand French,\r","O, then how quickly should this arm of mine.\r","Now prisoner to the palsy, chastise thee\r","And minister correction to thy fault!\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","My gracious uncle, let me know my fault:\r","On what condition stands it and wherein?\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Even in condition of the worst degree,\r","In gross rebellion and detested treason:\r","Thou art a banish'd man, and here art come\r","Before the expiration of thy time,\r","In braving arms against thy sovereign.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","As I was banish'd, I was banish'd Hereford;\r","But as I come, I come for Lancaster.\r","And, noble uncle, I beseech your grace\r","Look on my wrongs with an indifferent eye:\r","You are my father, for methinks in you\r","I see old Gaunt alive; O, then, my father,\r","Will you permit that I shall stand condemn'd\r","A wandering vagabond; my rights and royalties\r","Pluck'd from my arms perforce and given away\r","To upstart unthrifts? Wherefore was I born?\r","If that my cousin king be King of England,\r","It must be granted I am Duke of Lancaster.\r","You have a son, Aumerle, my noble cousin;\r","Had you first died, and he been thus trod down,\r","He should have found his uncle Gaunt a father,\r","To rouse his wrongs and chase them to the bay.\r","I am denied to sue my livery here,\r","And yet my letters-patents give me leave:\r","My father's goods are all distrain'd and sold,\r","And these and all are all amiss employ'd.\r","What would you have me do? I am a subject,\r","And I challenge law: attorneys are denied me;\r","And therefore, personally I lay my claim\r","To my inheritance of free descent.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","The noble duke hath been too much abused.\r","\r","LORD ROSS:\r","It stands your grace upon to do him right.\r","\r","LORD WILLOUGHBY:\r","Base men by his endowments are made great.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","My lords of England, let me tell you this:\r","I have had feeling of my cousin's wrongs\r","And laboured all I could to do him right;\r","But in this kind to come, in braving arms,\r","Be his own carver and cut out his way,\r","To find out right with wrong, it may not be;\r","And you that do abet him in this kind\r","Cherish rebellion and are rebels all.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","The noble duke hath sworn his coming is\r","But for his own; and for the right of that\r","We all have strongly sworn to give him aid;\r","And let him ne'er see joy that breaks that oath!\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Well, well, I see the issue of these arms:\r","I cannot mend it, I must needs confess,\r","Because my power is weak and all ill left:\r","But if I could, by Him that gave me life,\r","I would attach you all and make you stoop\r","Unto the sovereign mercy of the king;\r","But since I cannot, be it known to you\r","I do remain as neuter. So, fare you well;\r","Unless you please to enter in the castle\r","And there repose you for this night.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","An offer, uncle, that we will accept:\r","But we must win your grace to go with us\r","To Bristol castle, which they say is held\r","By Bushy, Bagot and their complices,\r","The caterpillars of the commonwealth,\r","Which I have sworn to weed and pluck away.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","It may be I will go with you: but yet I'll pause;\r","For I am loath to break our country's laws.\r","Nor friends nor foes, to me welcome you are:\r","Things past redress are now with me past care.\r","\r","Captain:\r","My lord of Salisbury, we have stay'd ten days,\r","And hardly kept our countrymen together,\r","And yet we hear no tidings from the king;\r","Therefore we will disperse ourselves: farewell.\r","\r","EARL OF SALISBURY:\r","Stay yet another day, thou trusty Welshman:\r","The king reposeth all his confidence in thee.\r","\r","Captain:\r","'Tis thought the king is dead; we will not stay.\r","The bay-trees in our country are all wither'd\r","And meteors fright the fixed stars of heaven;\r","The pale-faced moon looks bloody on the earth\r","And lean-look'd prophets whisper fearful change;\r","Rich men look sad and ruffians dance and leap,\r","The one in fear to lose what they enjoy,\r","The other to enjoy by rage and war:\r","These signs forerun the death or fall of kings.\r","Farewell: our countrymen are gone and fled,\r","As well assured Richard their king is dead.\r","\r","EARL OF SALISBURY:\r","Ah, Richard, with the eyes of heavy mind\r","I see thy glory like a shooting star\r","Fall to the base earth from the firmament.\r","Thy sun sets weeping in the lowly west,\r","Witnessing storms to come, woe and unrest:\r","Thy friends are fled to wait upon thy foes,\r","And crossly to thy good all fortune goes.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Bring forth these men.\r","Bushy and Green, I will not vex your souls--\r","Since presently your souls must part your bodies--\r","With too much urging your pernicious lives,\r","For 'twere no charity; yet, to wash your blood\r","From off my hands, here in the view of men\r","I will unfold some causes of your deaths.\r","You have misled a prince, a royal king,\r","A happy gentleman in blood and lineaments,\r","By you unhappied and disfigured clean:\r","You have in manner with your sinful hours\r","Made a divorce betwixt his queen and him,\r","Broke the possession of a royal bed\r","And stain'd the beauty of a fair queen's cheeks\r","With tears drawn from her eyes by your foul wrongs.\r","Myself, a prince by fortune of my birth,\r","Near to the king in blood, and near in love\r","Till you did make him misinterpret me,\r","Have stoop'd my neck under your injuries,\r","And sigh'd my English breath in foreign clouds,\r","Eating the bitter bread of banishment;\r","Whilst you have fed upon my signories,\r","Dispark'd my parks and fell'd my forest woods,\r","From my own windows torn my household coat,\r","Razed out my imprese, leaving me no sign,\r","Save men's opinions and my living blood,\r","To show the world I am a gentleman.\r","This and much more, much more than twice all this,\r","Condemns you to the death. See them deliver'd over\r","To execution and the hand of death.\r","\r","BUSHY:\r","More welcome is the stroke of death to me\r","Than Bolingbroke to England. Lords, farewell.\r","\r","GREEN:\r","My comfort is that heaven will take our souls\r","And plague injustice with the pains of hell.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","My Lord Northumberland, see them dispatch'd.\r","Uncle, you say the queen is at your house;\r","For God's sake, fairly let her be entreated:\r","Tell her I send to her my kind commends;\r","Take special care my greetings be deliver'd.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","A gentleman of mine I have dispatch'd\r","With letters of your love to her at large.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Thank, gentle uncle. Come, lords, away.\r","To fight with Glendower and his complices:\r","Awhile to work, and after holiday.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Barkloughly castle call they this at hand?\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","Yea, my lord. How brooks your grace the air,\r","After your late tossing on the breaking seas?\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Needs must I like it well: I weep for joy\r","To stand upon my kingdom once again.\r","Dear earth, I do salute thee with my hand,\r","Though rebels wound thee with their horses' hoofs:\r","As a long-parted mother with her child\r","Plays fondly with her tears and smiles in meeting,\r","So, weeping, smiling, greet I thee, my earth,\r","And do thee favours with my royal hands.\r","Feed not thy sovereign's foe, my gentle earth,\r","Nor with thy sweets comfort his ravenous sense;\r","But let thy spiders, that suck up thy venom,\r","And heavy-gaited toads lie in their way,\r","Doing annoyance to the treacherous feet\r","Which with usurping steps do trample thee:\r","Yield stinging nettles to mine enemies;\r","And when they from thy bosom pluck a flower,\r","Guard it, I pray thee, with a lurking adder\r","Whose double tongue may with a mortal touch\r","Throw death upon thy sovereign's enemies.\r","Mock not my senseless conjuration, lords:\r","This earth shall have a feeling and these stones\r","Prove armed soldiers, ere her native king\r","Shall falter under foul rebellion's arms.\r","\r","BISHOP OF CARLISLE:\r","Fear not, my lord: that Power that made you king\r","Hath power to keep you king in spite of all.\r","The means that heaven yields must be embraced,\r","And not neglected; else, if heaven would,\r","And we will not, heaven's offer we refuse,\r","The proffer'd means of succor and redress.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","He means, my lord, that we are too remiss;\r","Whilst Bolingbroke, through our security,\r","Grows strong and great in substance and in power.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Discomfortable cousin! know'st thou not\r","That when the searching eye of heaven is hid,\r","Behind the globe, that lights the lower world,\r","Then thieves and robbers range abroad unseen\r","In murders and in outrage, boldly here;\r","But when from under this terrestrial ball\r","He fires the proud tops of the eastern pines\r","And darts his light through every guilty hole,\r","Then murders, treasons and detested sins,\r","The cloak of night being pluck'd from off their backs,\r","Stand bare and naked, trembling at themselves?\r","So when this thief, this traitor, Bolingbroke,\r","Who all this while hath revell'd in the night\r","Whilst we were wandering with the antipodes,\r","Shall see us rising in our throne, the east,\r","His treasons will sit blushing in his face,\r","Not able to endure the sight of day,\r","But self-affrighted tremble at his sin.\r","Not all the water in the rough rude sea\r","Can wash the balm off from an anointed king;\r","The breath of worldly men cannot depose\r","The deputy elected by the Lord:\r","For every man that Bolingbroke hath press'd\r","To lift shrewd steel against our golden crown,\r","God for his Richard hath in heavenly pay\r","A glorious angel: then, if angels fight,\r","Weak men must fall, for heaven still guards the right.\r","Welcome, my lord how far off lies your power?\r","\r","EARL OF SALISBURY:\r","Nor near nor farther off, my gracious lord,\r","Than this weak arm: discomfort guides my tongue\r","And bids me speak of nothing but despair.\r","One day too late, I fear me, noble lord,\r","Hath clouded all thy happy days on earth:\r","O, call back yesterday, bid time return,\r","And thou shalt have twelve thousand fighting men!\r","To-day, to-day, unhappy day, too late,\r","O'erthrows thy joys, friends, fortune and thy state:\r","For all the Welshmen, hearing thou wert dead.\r","Are gone to Bolingbroke, dispersed and fled.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","Comfort, my liege; why looks your grace so pale?\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","But now the blood of twenty thousand men\r","Did triumph in my face, and they are fled;\r","And, till so much blood thither come again,\r","Have I not reason to look pale and dead?\r","All souls that will be safe fly from my side,\r","For time hath set a blot upon my pride.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","Comfort, my liege; remember who you are.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","I had forgot myself; am I not king?\r","Awake, thou coward majesty! thou sleepest.\r","Is not the king's name twenty thousand names?\r","Arm, arm, my name! a puny subject strikes\r","At thy great glory. Look not to the ground,\r","Ye favourites of a king: are we not high?\r","High be our thoughts: I know my uncle York\r","Hath power enough to serve our turn. But who comes here?\r","\r","SIR STEPHEN SCROOP:\r","More health and happiness betide my liege\r","Than can my care-tuned tongue deliver him!\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Mine ear is open and my heart prepared;\r","The worst is worldly loss thou canst unfold.\r","Say, is my kingdom lost? why, 'twas my care\r","And what loss is it to be rid of care?\r","Strives Bolingbroke to be as great as we?\r","Greater he shall not be; if he serve God,\r","We'll serve Him too and be his fellow so:\r","Revolt our subjects? that we cannot mend;\r","They break their faith to God as well as us:\r","Cry woe, destruction, ruin and decay:\r","The worst is death, and death will have his day.\r","\r","SIR STEPHEN SCROOP:\r","Glad am I that your highness is so arm'd\r","To bear the tidings of calamity.\r","Like an unseasonable stormy day,\r","Which makes the silver rivers drown their shores,\r","As if the world were all dissolved to tears,\r","So high above his limits swells the rage\r","Of Bolingbroke, covering your fearful land\r","With hard bright steel and hearts harder than steel.\r","White-beards have arm'd their thin and hairless scalps\r","Against thy majesty; boys, with women's voices,\r","Strive to speak big and clap their female joints\r","In stiff unwieldy arms against thy crown:\r","The very beadsmen learn to bend their bows\r","Of double-fatal yew against thy state;\r","Yea, distaff-women manage rusty bills\r","Against thy seat: both young and old rebel,\r","And all goes worse than I have power to tell.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Too well, too well thou tell'st a tale so ill.\r","Where is the Earl of Wiltshire? where is Bagot?\r","What is become of Bushy? where is Green?\r","That they have let the dangerous enemy\r","Measure our confines with such peaceful steps?\r","If we prevail, their heads shall pay for it:\r","I warrant they have made peace with Bolingbroke.\r","\r","SIR STEPHEN SCROOP:\r","Peace have they made with him indeed, my lord.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","O villains, vipers, damn'd without redemption!\r","Dogs, easily won to fawn on any man!\r","Snakes, in my heart-blood warm'd, that sting my heart!\r","Three Judases, each one thrice worse than Judas!\r","Would they make peace? terrible hell make war\r","Upon their spotted souls for this offence!\r","\r","SIR STEPHEN SCROOP:\r","Sweet love, I see, changing his property,\r","Turns to the sourest and most deadly hate:\r","Again uncurse their souls; their peace is made\r","With heads, and not with hands; those whom you curse\r","Have felt the worst of death's destroying wound\r","And lie full low, graved in the hollow ground.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","Is Bushy, Green, and the Earl of Wiltshire dead?\r","\r","SIR STEPHEN SCROOP:\r","Ay, all of them at Bristol lost their heads.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","Where is the duke my father with his power?\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","No matter where; of comfort no man speak:\r","Let's talk of graves, of worms, and epitaphs;\r","Make dust our paper and with rainy eyes\r","Write sorrow on the bosom of the earth,\r","Let's choose executors and talk of wills:\r","And yet not so, for what can we bequeath\r","Save our deposed bodies to the ground?\r","Our lands, our lives and all are Bolingbroke's,\r","And nothing can we call our own but death\r","And that small model of the barren earth\r","Which serves as paste and cover to our bones.\r","For God's sake, let us sit upon the ground\r","And tell sad stories of the death of kings;\r","How some have been deposed; some slain in war,\r","Some haunted by the ghosts they have deposed;\r","Some poison'd by their wives: some sleeping kill'd;\r","All murder'd: for within the hollow crown\r","That rounds the mortal temples of a king\r","Keeps Death his court and there the antic sits,\r","Scoffing his state and grinning at his pomp,\r","Allowing him a breath, a little scene,\r","To monarchize, be fear'd and kill with looks,\r","Infusing him with self and vain conceit,\r","As if this flesh which walls about our life,\r","Were brass impregnable, and humour'd thus\r","Comes at the last and with a little pin\r","Bores through his castle wall, and farewell king!\r","Cover your heads and mock not flesh and blood\r","With solemn reverence: throw away respect,\r","Tradition, form and ceremonious duty,\r","For you have but mistook me all this while:\r","I live with bread like you, feel want,\r","Taste grief, need friends: subjected thus,\r","How can you say to me, I am a king?\r","\r","BISHOP OF CARLISLE:\r","My lord, wise men ne'er sit and wail their woes,\r","But presently prevent the ways to wail.\r","To fear the foe, since fear oppresseth strength,\r","Gives in your weakness strength unto your foe,\r","And so your follies fight against yourself.\r","Fear and be slain; no worse can come to fight:\r","And fight and die is death destroying death;\r","Where fearing dying pays death servile breath.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","My father hath a power; inquire of him\r","And learn to make a body of a limb.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Thou chidest me well: proud Bolingbroke, I come\r","To change blows with thee for our day of doom.\r","This ague fit of fear is over-blown;\r","An easy task it is to win our own.\r","Say, Scroop, where lies our uncle with his power?\r","Speak sweetly, man, although thy looks be sour.\r","\r","SIR STEPHEN SCROOP:\r","Men judge by the complexion of the sky\r","The state and inclination of the day:\r","So may you by my dull and heavy eye,\r","My tongue hath but a heavier tale to say.\r","I play the torturer, by small and small\r","To lengthen out the worst that must be spoken:\r","Your uncle York is join'd with Bolingbroke,\r","And all your northern castles yielded up,\r","And all your southern gentlemen in arms\r","Upon his party.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Thou hast said enough.\r","Beshrew thee, cousin, which didst lead me forth\r","Of that sweet way I was in to despair!\r","What say you now? what comfort have we now?\r","By heaven, I'll hate him everlastingly\r","That bids me be of comfort any more.\r","Go to Flint castle: there I'll pine away;\r","A king, woe's slave, shall kingly woe obey.\r","That power I have, discharge; and let them go\r","To ear the land that hath some hope to grow,\r","For I have none: let no man speak again\r","To alter this, for counsel is but vain.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","My liege, one word.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","He does me double wrong\r","That wounds me with the flatteries of his tongue.\r","Discharge my followers: let them hence away,\r","From Richard's night to Bolingbroke's fair day.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","So that by this intelligence we learn\r","The Welshmen are dispersed, and Salisbury\r","Is gone to meet the king, who lately landed\r","With some few private friends upon this coast.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","The news is very fair and good, my lord:\r","Richard not far from hence hath hid his head.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","It would beseem the Lord Northumberland\r","To say 'King Richard:' alack the heavy day\r","When such a sacred king should hide his head.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","Your grace mistakes; only to be brief\r","Left I his title out.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","The time hath been,\r","Would you have been so brief with him, he would\r","Have been so brief with you, to shorten you,\r","For taking so the head, your whole head's length.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Mistake not, uncle, further than you should.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Take not, good cousin, further than you should.\r","Lest you mistake the heavens are o'er our heads.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","I know it, uncle, and oppose not myself\r","Against their will. But who comes here?\r","Welcome, Harry: what, will not this castle yield?\r","\r","HENRY PERCY:\r","The castle royally is mann'd, my lord,\r","Against thy entrance.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Royally!\r","Why, it contains no king?\r","\r","HENRY PERCY:\r","Yes, my good lord,\r","It doth contain a king; King Richard lies\r","Within the limits of yon lime and stone:\r","And with him are the Lord Aumerle, Lord Salisbury,\r","Sir Stephen Scroop, besides a clergyman\r","Of holy reverence; who, I cannot learn.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","O, belike it is the Bishop of Carlisle.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Noble lords,\r","Go to the rude ribs of that ancient castle;\r","Through brazen trumpet send the breath of parley\r","Into his ruin'd ears, and thus deliver:\r","Henry Bolingbroke\r","On both his knees doth kiss King Richard's hand\r","And sends allegiance and true faith of heart\r","To his most royal person, hither come\r","Even at his feet to lay my arms and power,\r","Provided that my banishment repeal'd\r","And lands restored again be freely granted:\r","If not, I'll use the advantage of my power\r","And lay the summer's dust with showers of blood\r","Rain'd from the wounds of slaughter'd Englishmen:\r","The which, how far off from the mind of Bolingbroke\r","It is, such crimson tempest should bedrench\r","The fresh green lap of fair King Richard's land,\r","My stooping duty tenderly shall show.\r","Go, signify as much, while here we march\r","Upon the grassy carpet of this plain.\r","Let's march without the noise of threatening drum,\r","That from this castle's tatter'd battlements\r","Our fair appointments may be well perused.\r","Methinks King Richard and myself should meet\r","With no less terror than the elements\r","Of fire and water, when their thundering shock\r","At meeting tears the cloudy cheeks of heaven.\r","Be he the fire, I'll be the yielding water:\r","The rage be his, whilst on the earth I rain\r","My waters; on the earth, and not on him.\r","March on, and mark King Richard how he looks.\r","See, see, King Richard doth himself appear,\r","As doth the blushing discontented sun\r","From out the fiery portal of the east,\r","When he perceives the envious clouds are bent\r","To dim his glory and to stain the track\r","Of his bright passage to the occident.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Yet looks he like a king: behold, his eye,\r","As bright as is the eagle's, lightens forth\r","Controlling majesty: alack, alack, for woe,\r","That any harm should stain so fair a show!\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","We are amazed; and thus long have we stood\r","To watch the fearful bending of thy knee,\r","Because we thought ourself thy lawful king:\r","And if we be, how dare thy joints forget\r","To pay their awful duty to our presence?\r","If we be not, show us the hand of God\r","That hath dismissed us from our stewardship;\r","For well we know, no hand of blood and bone\r","Can gripe the sacred handle of our sceptre,\r","Unless he do profane, steal, or usurp.\r","And though you think that all, as you have done,\r","Have torn their souls by turning them from us,\r","And we are barren and bereft of friends;\r","Yet know, my master, God omnipotent,\r","Is mustering in his clouds on our behalf\r","Armies of pestilence; and they shall strike\r","Your children yet unborn and unbegot,\r","That lift your vassal hands against my head\r","And threat the glory of my precious crown.\r","Tell Bolingbroke--for yond methinks he stands--\r","That every stride he makes upon my land\r","Is dangerous treason: he is come to open\r","The purple testament of bleeding war;\r","But ere the crown he looks for live in peace,\r","Ten thousand bloody crowns of mothers' sons\r","Shall ill become the flower of England's face,\r","Change the complexion of her maid-pale peace\r","To scarlet indignation and bedew\r","Her pastures' grass with faithful English blood.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","The king of heaven forbid our lord the king\r","Should so with civil and uncivil arms\r","Be rush'd upon! Thy thrice noble cousin\r","Harry Bolingbroke doth humbly kiss thy hand;\r","And by the honourable tomb he swears,\r","That stands upon your royal grandsire's bones,\r","And by the royalties of both your bloods,\r","Currents that spring from one most gracious head,\r","And by the buried hand of warlike Gaunt,\r","And by the worth and honour of himself,\r","Comprising all that may be sworn or said,\r","His coming hither hath no further scope\r","Than for his lineal royalties and to beg\r","Enfranchisement immediate on his knees:\r","Which on thy royal party granted once,\r","His glittering arms he will commend to rust,\r","His barbed steeds to stables, and his heart\r","To faithful service of your majesty.\r","This swears he, as he is a prince, is just;\r","And, as I am a gentleman, I credit him.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Northumberland, say thus the king returns:\r","His noble cousin is right welcome hither;\r","And all the number of his fair demands\r","Shall be accomplish'd without contradiction:\r","With all the gracious utterance thou hast\r","Speak to his gentle hearing kind commends.\r","We do debase ourselves, cousin, do we not,\r","To look so poorly and to speak so fair?\r","Shall we call back Northumberland, and send\r","Defiance to the traitor, and so die?\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","No, good my lord; let's fight with gentle words\r","Till time lend friends and friends their helpful swords.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","O God, O God! that e'er this tongue of mine,\r","That laid the sentence of dread banishment\r","On yon proud man, should take it off again\r","With words of sooth! O that I were as great\r","As is my grief, or lesser than my name!\r","Or that I could forget what I have been,\r","Or not remember what I must be now!\r","Swell'st thou, proud heart? I'll give thee scope to beat,\r","Since foes have scope to beat both thee and me.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","Northumberland comes back from Bolingbroke.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","What must the king do now? must he submit?\r","The king shall do it: must he be deposed?\r","The king shall be contented: must he lose\r","The name of king? o' God's name, let it go:\r","I'll give my jewels for a set of beads,\r","My gorgeous palace for a hermitage,\r","My gay apparel for an almsman's gown,\r","My figured goblets for a dish of wood,\r","My sceptre for a palmer's walking staff,\r","My subjects for a pair of carved saints\r","And my large kingdom for a little grave,\r","A little little grave, an obscure grave;\r","Or I'll be buried in the king's highway,\r","Some way of common trade, where subjects' feet\r","May hourly trample on their sovereign's head;\r","For on my heart they tread now whilst I live;\r","And buried once, why not upon my head?\r","Aumerle, thou weep'st, my tender-hearted cousin!\r","We'll make foul weather with despised tears;\r","Our sighs and they shall lodge the summer corn,\r","And make a dearth in this revolting land.\r","Or shall we play the wantons with our woes,\r","And make some pretty match with shedding tears?\r","As thus, to drop them still upon one place,\r","Till they have fretted us a pair of graves\r","Within the earth; and, therein laid,--there lies\r","Two kinsmen digg'd their graves with weeping eyes.\r","Would not this ill do well? Well, well, I see\r","I talk but idly, and you laugh at me.\r","Most mighty prince, my Lord Northumberland,\r","What says King Bolingbroke? will his majesty\r","Give Richard leave to live till Richard die?\r","You make a leg, and Bolingbroke says ay.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","My lord, in the base court he doth attend\r","To speak with you; may it please you to come down.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Down, down I come; like glistering Phaethon,\r","Wanting the manage of unruly jades.\r","In the base court? Base court, where kings grow base,\r","To come at traitors' calls and do them grace.\r","In the base court? Come down? Down, court!\r","down, king!\r","For night-owls shriek where mounting larks\r","should sing.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","What says his majesty?\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","Sorrow and grief of heart\r","Makes him speak fondly, like a frantic man\r","Yet he is come.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Stand all apart,\r","And show fair duty to his majesty.\r","My gracious lord,--\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Fair cousin, you debase your princely knee\r","To make the base earth proud with kissing it:\r","Me rather had my heart might feel your love\r","Than my unpleased eye see your courtesy.\r","Up, cousin, up; your heart is up, I know,\r","Thus high at least, although your knee be low.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","My gracious lord, I come but for mine own.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Your own is yours, and I am yours, and all.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","So far be mine, my most redoubted lord,\r","As my true service shall deserve your love.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Well you deserve: they well deserve to have,\r","That know the strong'st and surest way to get.\r","Uncle, give me your hands: nay, dry your eyes;\r","Tears show their love, but want their remedies.\r","Cousin, I am too young to be your father,\r","Though you are old enough to be my heir.\r","What you will have, I'll give, and willing too;\r","For do we must what force will have us do.\r","Set on towards London, cousin, is it so?\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Yea, my good lord.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Then I must not say no.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","What sport shall we devise here in this garden,\r","To drive away the heavy thought of care?\r","\r","Lady:\r","Madam, we'll play at bowls.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","'Twill make me think the world is full of rubs,\r","And that my fortune rubs against the bias.\r","\r","Lady:\r","Madam, we'll dance.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","My legs can keep no measure in delight,\r","When my poor heart no measure keeps in grief:\r","Therefore, no dancing, girl; some other sport.\r","\r","Lady:\r","Madam, we'll tell tales.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","Of sorrow or of joy?\r","\r","Lady:\r","Of either, madam.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","Of neither, girl:\r","For of joy, being altogether wanting,\r","It doth remember me the more of sorrow;\r","Or if of grief, being altogether had,\r","It adds more sorrow to my want of joy:\r","For what I have I need not to repeat;\r","And what I want it boots not to complain.\r","\r","Lady:\r","Madam, I'll sing.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","'Tis well that thou hast cause\r","But thou shouldst please me better, wouldst thou weep.\r","\r","Lady:\r","I could weep, madam, would it do you good.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","And I could sing, would weeping do me good,\r","And never borrow any tear of thee.\r","But stay, here come the gardeners:\r","Let's step into the shadow of these trees.\r","My wretchedness unto a row of pins,\r","They'll talk of state; for every one doth so\r","Against a change; woe is forerun with woe.\r","\r","Gardener:\r","Go, bind thou up yon dangling apricocks,\r","Which, like unruly children, make their sire\r","Stoop with oppression of their prodigal weight:\r","Give some supportance to the bending twigs.\r","Go thou, and like an executioner,\r","Cut off the heads of too fast growing sprays,\r","That look too lofty in our commonwealth:\r","All must be even in our government.\r","You thus employ'd, I will go root away\r","The noisome weeds, which without profit suck\r","The soil's fertility from wholesome flowers.\r","\r","Servant:\r","Why should we in the compass of a pale\r","Keep law and form and due proportion,\r","Showing, as in a model, our firm estate,\r","When our sea-walled garden, the whole land,\r","Is full of weeds, her fairest flowers choked up,\r","Her fruit-trees all upturned, her hedges ruin'd,\r","Her knots disorder'd and her wholesome herbs\r","Swarming with caterpillars?\r","\r","Gardener:\r","Hold thy peace:\r","He that hath suffer'd this disorder'd spring\r","Hath now himself met with the fall of leaf:\r","The weeds which his broad-spreading leaves did shelter,\r","That seem'd in eating him to hold him up,\r","Are pluck'd up root and all by Bolingbroke,\r","I mean the Earl of Wiltshire, Bushy, Green.\r","\r","Servant:\r","What, are they dead?\r","\r","Gardener:\r","They are; and Bolingbroke\r","Hath seized the wasteful king. O, what pity is it\r","That he had not so trimm'd and dress'd his land\r","As we this garden! We at time of year\r","Do wound the bark, the skin of our fruit-trees,\r","Lest, being over-proud in sap and blood,\r","With too much riches it confound itself:\r","Had he done so to great and growing men,\r","They might have lived to bear and he to taste\r","Their fruits of duty: superfluous branches\r","We lop away, that bearing boughs may live:\r","Had he done so, himself had borne the crown,\r","Which waste of idle hours hath quite thrown down.\r","\r","Servant:\r","What, think you then the king shall be deposed?\r","\r","Gardener:\r","Depress'd he is already, and deposed\r","'Tis doubt he will be: letters came last night\r","To a dear friend of the good Duke of York's,\r","That tell black tidings.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","O, I am press'd to death through want of speaking!\r","Thou, old Adam's likeness, set to dress this garden,\r","How dares thy harsh rude tongue sound this unpleasing news?\r","What Eve, what serpent, hath suggested thee\r","To make a second fall of cursed man?\r","Why dost thou say King Richard is deposed?\r","Darest thou, thou little better thing than earth,\r","Divine his downfall? Say, where, when, and how,\r","Camest thou by this ill tidings? speak, thou wretch.\r","\r","Gardener:\r","Pardon me, madam: little joy have I\r","To breathe this news; yet what I say is true.\r","King Richard, he is in the mighty hold\r","Of Bolingbroke: their fortunes both are weigh'd:\r","In your lord's scale is nothing but himself,\r","And some few vanities that make him light;\r","But in the balance of great Bolingbroke,\r","Besides himself, are all the English peers,\r","And with that odds he weighs King Richard down.\r","Post you to London, and you will find it so;\r","I speak no more than every one doth know.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","Nimble mischance, that art so light of foot,\r","Doth not thy embassage belong to me,\r","And am I last that knows it? O, thou think'st\r","To serve me last, that I may longest keep\r","Thy sorrow in my breast. Come, ladies, go,\r","To meet at London London's king in woe.\r","What, was I born to this, that my sad look\r","Should grace the triumph of great Bolingbroke?\r","Gardener, for telling me these news of woe,\r","Pray God the plants thou graft'st may never grow.\r","\r","GARDENER:\r","Poor queen! so that thy state might be no worse,\r","I would my skill were subject to thy curse.\r","Here did she fall a tear; here in this place\r","I'll set a bank of rue, sour herb of grace:\r","Rue, even for ruth, here shortly shall be seen,\r","In the remembrance of a weeping queen.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Call forth Bagot.\r","Now, Bagot, freely speak thy mind;\r","What thou dost know of noble Gloucester's death,\r","Who wrought it with the king, and who perform'd\r","The bloody office of his timeless end.\r","\r","BAGOT:\r","Then set before my face the Lord Aumerle.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Cousin, stand forth, and look upon that man.\r","\r","BAGOT:\r","My Lord Aumerle, I know your daring tongue\r","Scorns to unsay what once it hath deliver'd.\r","In that dead time when Gloucester's death was plotted,\r","I heard you say, 'Is not my arm of length,\r","That reacheth from the restful English court\r","As far as Calais, to mine uncle's head?'\r","Amongst much other talk, that very time,\r","I heard you say that you had rather refuse\r","The offer of an hundred thousand crowns\r","Than Bolingbroke's return to England;\r","Adding withal how blest this land would be\r","In this your cousin's death.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","Princes and noble lords,\r","What answer shall I make to this base man?\r","Shall I so much dishonour my fair stars,\r","On equal terms to give him chastisement?\r","Either I must, or have mine honour soil'd\r","With the attainder of his slanderous lips.\r","There is my gage, the manual seal of death,\r","That marks thee out for hell: I say, thou liest,\r","And will maintain what thou hast said is false\r","In thy heart-blood, though being all too base\r","To stain the temper of my knightly sword.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Bagot, forbear; thou shalt not take it up.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","Excepting one, I would he were the best\r","In all this presence that hath moved me so.\r","\r","LORD FITZWATER:\r","If that thy valour stand on sympathy,\r","There is my gage, Aumerle, in gage to thine:\r","By that fair sun which shows me where thou stand'st,\r","I heard thee say, and vauntingly thou spakest it\r","That thou wert cause of noble Gloucester's death.\r","If thou deny'st it twenty times, thou liest;\r","And I will turn thy falsehood to thy heart,\r","Where it was forged, with my rapier's point.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","Thou darest not, coward, live to see that day.\r","\r","LORD FITZWATER:\r","Now by my soul, I would it were this hour.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","Fitzwater, thou art damn'd to hell for this.\r","\r","HENRY PERCY:\r","Aumerle, thou liest; his honour is as true\r","In this appeal as thou art all unjust;\r","And that thou art so, there I throw my gage,\r","To prove it on thee to the extremest point\r","Of mortal breathing: seize it, if thou darest.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","An if I do not, may my hands rot off\r","And never brandish more revengeful steel\r","Over the glittering helmet of my foe!\r","\r","Lord:\r","I task the earth to the like, forsworn Aumerle;\r","And spur thee on with full as many lies\r","As may be holloa'd in thy treacherous ear\r","From sun to sun: there is my honour's pawn;\r","Engage it to the trial, if thou darest.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","Who sets me else? by heaven, I'll throw at all:\r","I have a thousand spirits in one breast,\r","To answer twenty thousand such as you.\r","\r","DUKE OF SURREY:\r","My Lord Fitzwater, I do remember well\r","The very time Aumerle and you did talk.\r","\r","LORD FITZWATER:\r","'Tis very true: you were in presence then;\r","And you can witness with me this is true.\r","\r","DUKE OF SURREY:\r","As false, by heaven, as heaven itself is true.\r","\r","LORD FITZWATER:\r","Surrey, thou liest.\r","\r","DUKE OF SURREY:\r","Dishonourable boy!\r","That lie shall lie so heavy on my sword,\r","That it shall render vengeance and revenge\r","Till thou the lie-giver and that lie do lie\r","In earth as quiet as thy father's skull:\r","In proof whereof, there is my honour's pawn;\r","Engage it to the trial, if thou darest.\r","\r","LORD FITZWATER:\r","How fondly dost thou spur a forward horse!\r","If I dare eat, or drink, or breathe, or live,\r","I dare meet Surrey in a wilderness,\r","And spit upon him, whilst I say he lies,\r","And lies, and lies: there is my bond of faith,\r","To tie thee to my strong correction.\r","As I intend to thrive in this new world,\r","Aumerle is guilty of my true appeal:\r","Besides, I heard the banish'd Norfolk say\r","That thou, Aumerle, didst send two of thy men\r","To execute the noble duke at Calais.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","Some honest Christian trust me with a gage\r","That Norfolk lies: here do I throw down this,\r","If he may be repeal'd, to try his honour.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","These differences shall all rest under gage\r","Till Norfolk be repeal'd: repeal'd he shall be,\r","And, though mine enemy, restored again\r","To all his lands and signories: when he's return'd,\r","Against Aumerle we will enforce his trial.\r","\r","BISHOP OF CARLISLE:\r","That honourable day shall ne'er be seen.\r","Many a time hath banish'd Norfolk fought\r","For Jesu Christ in glorious Christian field,\r","Streaming the ensign of the Christian cross\r","Against black pagans, Turks, and Saracens:\r","And toil'd with works of war, retired himself\r","To Italy; and there at Venice gave\r","His body to that pleasant country's earth,\r","And his pure soul unto his captain Christ,\r","Under whose colours he had fought so long.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Why, bishop, is Norfolk dead?\r","\r","BISHOP OF CARLISLE:\r","As surely as I live, my lord.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Sweet peace conduct his sweet soul to the bosom\r","Of good old Abraham! Lords appellants,\r","Your differences shall all rest under gage\r","Till we assign you to your days of trial.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Great Duke of Lancaster, I come to thee\r","From plume-pluck'd Richard; who with willing soul\r","Adopts thee heir, and his high sceptre yields\r","To the possession of thy royal hand:\r","Ascend his throne, descending now from him;\r","And long live Henry, fourth of that name!\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","In God's name, I'll ascend the regal throne.\r","\r","BISHOP OF CARLISLE:\r","Marry. God forbid!\r","Worst in this royal presence may I speak,\r","Yet best beseeming me to speak the truth.\r","Would God that any in this noble presence\r","Were enough noble to be upright judge\r","Of noble Richard! then true noblesse would\r","Learn him forbearance from so foul a wrong.\r","What subject can give sentence on his king?\r","And who sits here that is not Richard's subject?\r","Thieves are not judged but they are by to hear,\r","Although apparent guilt be seen in them;\r","And shall the figure of God's majesty,\r","His captain, steward, deputy-elect,\r","Anointed, crowned, planted many years,\r","Be judged by subject and inferior breath,\r","And he himself not present? O, forfend it, God,\r","That in a Christian climate souls refined\r","Should show so heinous, black, obscene a deed!\r","I speak to subjects, and a subject speaks,\r","Stirr'd up by God, thus boldly for his king:\r","My Lord of Hereford here, whom you call king,\r","Is a foul traitor to proud Hereford's king:\r","And if you crown him, let me prophesy:\r","The blood of English shall manure the ground,\r","And future ages groan for this foul act;\r","Peace shall go sleep with Turks and infidels,\r","And in this seat of peace tumultuous wars\r","Shall kin with kin and kind with kind confound;\r","Disorder, horror, fear and mutiny\r","Shall here inhabit, and this land be call'd\r","The field of Golgotha and dead men's skulls.\r","O, if you raise this house against this house,\r","It will the woefullest division prove\r","That ever fell upon this cursed earth.\r","Prevent it, resist it, let it not be so,\r","Lest child, child's children, cry against you woe!\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","Well have you argued, sir; and, for your pains,\r","Of capital treason we arrest you here.\r","My Lord of Westminster, be it your charge\r","To keep him safely till his day of trial.\r","May it please you, lords, to grant the commons' suit.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Fetch hither Richard, that in common view\r","He may surrender; so we shall proceed\r","Without suspicion.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","I will be his conduct.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Lords, you that here are under our arrest,\r","Procure your sureties for your days of answer.\r","Little are we beholding to your love,\r","And little look'd for at your helping hands.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Alack, why am I sent for to a king,\r","Before I have shook off the regal thoughts\r","Wherewith I reign'd? I hardly yet have learn'd\r","To insinuate, flatter, bow, and bend my limbs:\r","Give sorrow leave awhile to tutor me\r","To this submission. Yet I well remember\r","The favours of these men: were they not mine?\r","Did they not sometime cry, 'all hail!' to me?\r","So Judas did to Christ: but he, in twelve,\r","Found truth in all but one: I, in twelve thousand, none.\r","God save the king! Will no man say amen?\r","Am I both priest and clerk? well then, amen.\r","God save the king! although I be not he;\r","And yet, amen, if heaven do think him me.\r","To do what service am I sent for hither?\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","To do that office of thine own good will\r","Which tired majesty did make thee offer,\r","The resignation of thy state and crown\r","To Henry Bolingbroke.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Give me the crown. Here, cousin, seize the crown;\r","Here cousin:\r","On this side my hand, and on that side yours.\r","Now is this golden crown like a deep well\r","That owes two buckets, filling one another,\r","The emptier ever dancing in the air,\r","The other down, unseen and full of water:\r","That bucket down and full of tears am I,\r","Drinking my griefs, whilst you mount up on high.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","I thought you had been willing to resign.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","My crown I am; but still my griefs are mine:\r","You may my glories and my state depose,\r","But not my griefs; still am I king of those.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Part of your cares you give me with your crown.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Your cares set up do not pluck my cares down.\r","My care is loss of care, by old care done;\r","Your care is gain of care, by new care won:\r","The cares I give I have, though given away;\r","They tend the crown, yet still with me they stay.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Are you contented to resign the crown?\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Ay, no; no, ay; for I must nothing be;\r","Therefore no no, for I resign to thee.\r","Now mark me, how I will undo myself;\r","I give this heavy weight from off my head\r","And this unwieldy sceptre from my hand,\r","The pride of kingly sway from out my heart;\r","With mine own tears I wash away my balm,\r","With mine own hands I give away my crown,\r","With mine own tongue deny my sacred state,\r","With mine own breath release all duty's rites:\r","All pomp and majesty I do forswear;\r","My manors, rents, revenues I forego;\r","My acts, decrees, and statutes I deny:\r","God pardon all oaths that are broke to me!\r","God keep all vows unbroke that swear to thee!\r","Make me, that nothing have, with nothing grieved,\r","And thou with all pleased, that hast all achieved!\r","Long mayst thou live in Richard's seat to sit,\r","And soon lie Richard in an earthly pit!\r","God save King Harry, unking'd Richard says,\r","And send him many years of sunshine days!\r","What more remains?\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","No more, but that you read\r","These accusations and these grievous crimes\r","Committed by your person and your followers\r","Against the state and profit of this land;\r","That, by confessing them, the souls of men\r","May deem that you are worthily deposed.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Must I do so? and must I ravel out\r","My weaved-up folly? Gentle Northumberland,\r","If thy offences were upon record,\r","Would it not shame thee in so fair a troop\r","To read a lecture of them? If thou wouldst,\r","There shouldst thou find one heinous article,\r","Containing the deposing of a king\r","And cracking the strong warrant of an oath,\r","Mark'd with a blot, damn'd in the book of heaven:\r","Nay, all of you that stand and look upon,\r","Whilst that my wretchedness doth bait myself,\r","Though some of you with Pilate wash your hands\r","Showing an outward pity; yet you Pilates\r","Have here deliver'd me to my sour cross,\r","And water cannot wash away your sin.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","My lord, dispatch; read o'er these articles.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Mine eyes are full of tears, I cannot see:\r","And yet salt water blinds them not so much\r","But they can see a sort of traitors here.\r","Nay, if I turn mine eyes upon myself,\r","I find myself a traitor with the rest;\r","For I have given here my soul's consent\r","To undeck the pompous body of a king;\r","Made glory base and sovereignty a slave,\r","Proud majesty a subject, state a peasant.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","My lord,--\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","No lord of thine, thou haught insulting man,\r","Nor no man's lord; I have no name, no title,\r","No, not that name was given me at the font,\r","But 'tis usurp'd: alack the heavy day,\r","That I have worn so many winters out,\r","And know not now what name to call myself!\r","O that I were a mockery king of snow,\r","Standing before the sun of Bolingbroke,\r","To melt myself away in water-drops!\r","Good king, great king, and yet not greatly good,\r","An if my word be sterling yet in England,\r","Let it command a mirror hither straight,\r","That it may show me what a face I have,\r","Since it is bankrupt of his majesty.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Go some of you and fetch a looking-glass.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","Read o'er this paper while the glass doth come.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Fiend, thou torment'st me ere I come to hell!\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Urge it no more, my Lord Northumberland.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","The commons will not then be satisfied.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","They shall be satisfied: I'll read enough,\r","When I do see the very book indeed\r","Where all my sins are writ, and that's myself.\r","Give me the glass, and therein will I read.\r","No deeper wrinkles yet? hath sorrow struck\r","So many blows upon this face of mine,\r","And made no deeper wounds? O flattering glass,\r","Like to my followers in prosperity,\r","Thou dost beguile me! Was this face the face\r","That every day under his household roof\r","Did keep ten thousand men? was this the face\r","That, like the sun, did make beholders wink?\r","Was this the face that faced so many follies,\r","And was at last out-faced by Bolingbroke?\r","A brittle glory shineth in this face:\r","As brittle as the glory is the face;\r","For there it is, crack'd in a hundred shivers.\r","Mark, silent king, the moral of this sport,\r","How soon my sorrow hath destroy'd my face.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","The shadow of your sorrow hath destroy'd\r","The shadow or your face.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Say that again.\r","The shadow of my sorrow! ha! let's see:\r","'Tis very true, my grief lies all within;\r","And these external manners of laments\r","Are merely shadows to the unseen grief\r","That swells with silence in the tortured soul;\r","There lies the substance: and I thank thee, king,\r","For thy great bounty, that not only givest\r","Me cause to wail but teachest me the way\r","How to lament the cause. I'll beg one boon,\r","And then be gone and trouble you no more.\r","Shall I obtain it?\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Name it, fair cousin.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","'Fair cousin'? I am greater than a king:\r","For when I was a king, my flatterers\r","Were then but subjects; being now a subject,\r","I have a king here to my flatterer.\r","Being so great, I have no need to beg.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Yet ask.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","And shall I have?\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","You shall.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Then give me leave to go.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Whither?\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Whither you will, so I were from your sights.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Go, some of you convey him to the Tower.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","O, good! convey? conveyers are you all,\r","That rise thus nimbly by a true king's fall.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","On Wednesday next we solemnly set down\r","Our coronation: lords, prepare yourselves.\r","\r","Abbot:\r","A woeful pageant have we here beheld.\r","\r","BISHOP OF CARLISLE:\r","The woe's to come; the children yet unborn.\r","Shall feel this day as sharp to them as thorn.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","You holy clergymen, is there no plot\r","To rid the realm of this pernicious blot?\r","\r","Abbot:\r","My lord,\r","Before I freely speak my mind herein,\r","You shall not only take the sacrament\r","To bury mine intents, but also to effect\r","Whatever I shall happen to devise.\r","I see your brows are full of discontent,\r","Your hearts of sorrow and your eyes of tears:\r","Come home with me to supper; and I'll lay\r","A plot shall show us all a merry day.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","This way the king will come; this is the way\r","To Julius Caesar's ill-erected tower,\r","To whose flint bosom my condemned lord\r","Is doom'd a prisoner by proud Bolingbroke:\r","Here let us rest, if this rebellious earth\r","Have any resting for her true king's queen.\r","But soft, but see, or rather do not see,\r","My fair rose wither: yet look up, behold,\r","That you in pity may dissolve to dew,\r","And wash him fresh again with true-love tears.\r","Ah, thou, the model where old Troy did stand,\r","Thou map of honour, thou King Richard's tomb,\r","And not King Richard; thou most beauteous inn,\r","Why should hard-favour'd grief be lodged in thee,\r","When triumph is become an alehouse guest?\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Join not with grief, fair woman, do not so,\r","To make my end too sudden: learn, good soul,\r","To think our former state a happy dream;\r","From which awaked, the truth of what we are\r","Shows us but this: I am sworn brother, sweet,\r","To grim Necessity, and he and I\r","Will keep a league till death.
