Hie thee to France\r","And cloister thee in some religious house:\r","Our holy lives must win a new world's crown,\r","Which our profane hours here have stricken down.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","What, is my Richard both in shape and mind\r","Transform'd and weaken'd? hath Bolingbroke deposed\r","Thine intellect? hath he been in thy heart?\r","The lion dying thrusteth forth his paw,\r","And wounds the earth, if nothing else, with rage\r","To be o'erpower'd; and wilt thou, pupil-like,\r","Take thy correction mildly, kiss the rod,\r","And fawn on rage with base humility,\r","Which art a lion and a king of beasts?\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","A king of beasts, indeed; if aught but beasts,\r","I had been still a happy king of men.\r","Good sometime queen, prepare thee hence for France:\r","Think I am dead and that even here thou takest,\r","As from my death-bed, thy last living leave.\r","In winter's tedious nights sit by the fire\r","With good old folks and let them tell thee tales\r","Of woeful ages long ago betid;\r","And ere thou bid good night, to quit their griefs,\r","Tell thou the lamentable tale of me\r","And send the hearers weeping to their beds:\r","For why, the senseless brands will sympathize\r","The heavy accent of thy moving tongue\r","And in compassion weep the fire out;\r","And some will mourn in ashes, some coal-black,\r","For the deposing of a rightful king.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","My lord, the mind of Bolingbroke is changed:\r","You must to Pomfret, not unto the Tower.\r","And, madam, there is order ta'en for you;\r","With all swift speed you must away to France.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Northumberland, thou ladder wherewithal\r","The mounting Bolingbroke ascends my throne,\r","The time shall not be many hours of age\r","More than it is ere foul sin gathering head\r","Shalt break into corruption: thou shalt think,\r","Though he divide the realm and give thee half,\r","It is too little, helping him to all;\r","And he shall think that thou, which know'st the way\r","To plant unrightful kings, wilt know again,\r","Being ne'er so little urged, another way\r","To pluck him headlong from the usurped throne.\r","The love of wicked men converts to fear;\r","That fear to hate, and hate turns one or both\r","To worthy danger and deserved death.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","My guilt be on my head, and there an end.\r","Take leave and part; for you must part forthwith.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Doubly divorced! Bad men, you violate\r","A twofold marriage, 'twixt my crown and me,\r","And then betwixt me and my married wife.\r","Let me unkiss the oath 'twixt thee and me;\r","And yet not so, for with a kiss 'twas made.\r","Part us, Northumberland; I toward the north,\r","Where shivering cold and sickness pines the clime;\r","My wife to France: from whence, set forth in pomp,\r","She came adorned hither like sweet May,\r","Sent back like Hallowmas or short'st of day.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","And must we be divided? must we part?\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Ay, hand from hand, my love, and heart from heart.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","Banish us both and send the king with me.\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","That were some love but little policy.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","Then whither he goes, thither let me go.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","So two, together weeping, make one woe.\r","Weep thou for me in France, I for thee here;\r","Better far off than near, be ne'er the near.\r","Go, count thy way with sighs; I mine with groans.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","So longest way shall have the longest moans.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Twice for one step I'll groan, the way being short,\r","And piece the way out with a heavy heart.\r","Come, come, in wooing sorrow let's be brief,\r","Since, wedding it, there is such length in grief;\r","One kiss shall stop our mouths, and dumbly part;\r","Thus give I mine, and thus take I thy heart.\r","\r","QUEEN:\r","Give me mine own again; 'twere no good part\r","To take on me to keep and kill thy heart.\r","So, now I have mine own again, be gone,\r","That I might strive to kill it with a groan.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","We make woe wanton with this fond delay:\r","Once more, adieu; the rest let sorrow say.\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","My lord, you told me you would tell the rest,\r","When weeping made you break the story off,\r","of our two cousins coming into London.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Where did I leave?\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","At that sad stop, my lord,\r","Where rude misgovern'd hands from windows' tops\r","Threw dust and rubbish on King Richard's head.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Then, as I said, the duke, great Bolingbroke,\r","Mounted upon a hot and fiery steed\r","Which his aspiring rider seem'd to know,\r","With slow but stately pace kept on his course,\r","Whilst all tongues cried 'God save thee,\r","Bolingbroke!'\r","You would have thought the very windows spake,\r","So many greedy looks of young and old\r","Through casements darted their desiring eyes\r","Upon his visage, and that all the walls\r","With painted imagery had said at once\r","'Jesu preserve thee! welcome, Bolingbroke!'\r","Whilst he, from the one side to the other turning,\r","Bareheaded, lower than his proud steed's neck,\r","Bespake them thus: 'I thank you, countrymen:'\r","And thus still doing, thus he pass'd along.\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","Alack, poor Richard! where rode he the whilst?\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","As in a theatre, the eyes of men,\r","After a well-graced actor leaves the stage,\r","Are idly bent on him that enters next,\r","Thinking his prattle to be tedious;\r","Even so, or with much more contempt, men's eyes\r","Did scowl on gentle Richard; no man cried 'God save him!'\r","No joyful tongue gave him his welcome home:\r","But dust was thrown upon his sacred head:\r","Which with such gentle sorrow he shook off,\r","His face still combating with tears and smiles,\r","The badges of his grief and patience,\r","That had not God, for some strong purpose, steel'd\r","The hearts of men, they must perforce have melted\r","And barbarism itself have pitied him.\r","But heaven hath a hand in these events,\r","To whose high will we bound our calm contents.\r","To Bolingbroke are we sworn subjects now,\r","Whose state and honour I for aye allow.\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","Here comes my son Aumerle.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Aumerle that was;\r","But that is lost for being Richard's friend,\r","And, madam, you must call him Rutland now:\r","I am in parliament pledge for his truth\r","And lasting fealty to the new-made king.\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","Welcome, my son: who are the violets now\r","That strew the green lap of the new come spring?\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","Madam, I know not, nor I greatly care not:\r","God knows I had as lief be none as one.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Well, bear you well in this new spring of time,\r","Lest you be cropp'd before you come to prime.\r","What news from Oxford? hold those justs and triumphs?\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","For aught I know, my lord, they do.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","You will be there, I know.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","If God prevent not, I purpose so.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","What seal is that, that hangs without thy bosom?\r","Yea, look'st thou pale? let me see the writing.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","My lord, 'tis nothing.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","No matter, then, who see it;\r","I will be satisfied; let me see the writing.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","I do beseech your grace to pardon me:\r","It is a matter of small consequence,\r","Which for some reasons I would not have seen.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Which for some reasons, sir, I mean to see.\r","I fear, I fear,--\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","What should you fear?\r","'Tis nothing but some bond, that he is enter'd into\r","For gay apparel 'gainst the triumph day.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Bound to himself! what doth he with a bond\r","That he is bound to? Wife, thou art a fool.\r","Boy, let me see the writing.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","I do beseech you, pardon me; I may not show it.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","I will be satisfied; let me see it, I say.\r","Treason! foul treason! Villain! traitor! slave!\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","What is the matter, my lord?\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Ho! who is within there?\r","Saddle my horse.\r","God for his mercy, what treachery is here!\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","Why, what is it, my lord?\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Give me my boots, I say; saddle my horse.\r","Now, by mine honour, by my life, by my troth,\r","I will appeach the villain.\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","What is the matter?\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Peace, foolish woman.\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","I will not peace. What is the matter, Aumerle.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","Good mother, be content; it is no more\r","Than my poor life must answer.\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","Thy life answer!\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Bring me my boots: I will unto the king.\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","Strike him, Aumerle. Poor boy, thou art amazed.\r","Hence, villain! never more come in my sight.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Give me my boots, I say.\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","Why, York, what wilt thou do?\r","Wilt thou not hide the trespass of thine own?\r","Have we more sons? or are we like to have?\r","Is not my teeming date drunk up with time?\r","And wilt thou pluck my fair son from mine age,\r","And rob me of a happy mother's name?\r","Is he not like thee? is he not thine own?\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Thou fond mad woman,\r","Wilt thou conceal this dark conspiracy?\r","A dozen of them here have ta'en the sacrament,\r","And interchangeably set down their hands,\r","To kill the king at Oxford.\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","He shall be none;\r","We'll keep him here: then what is that to him?\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Away, fond woman! were he twenty times my son,\r","I would appeach him.\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","Hadst thou groan'd for him\r","As I have done, thou wouldst be more pitiful.\r","But now I know thy mind; thou dost suspect\r","That I have been disloyal to thy bed,\r","And that he is a bastard, not thy son:\r","Sweet York, sweet husband, be not of that mind:\r","He is as like thee as a man may be,\r","Not like to me, or any of my kin,\r","And yet I love him.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Make way, unruly woman!\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","After, Aumerle! mount thee upon his horse;\r","Spur post, and get before him to the king,\r","And beg thy pardon ere he do accuse thee.\r","I'll not be long behind; though I be old,\r","I doubt not but to ride as fast as York:\r","And never will I rise up from the ground\r","Till Bolingbroke have pardon'd thee. Away, be gone!\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Can no man tell me of my unthrifty son?\r","'Tis full three months since I did see him last;\r","If any plague hang over us, 'tis he.\r","I would to God, my lords, he might be found:\r","Inquire at London, 'mongst the taverns there,\r","For there, they say, he daily doth frequent,\r","With unrestrained loose companions,\r","Even such, they say, as stand in narrow lanes,\r","And beat our watch, and rob our passengers;\r","Which he, young wanton and effeminate boy,\r","Takes on the point of honour to support\r","So dissolute a crew.\r","\r","HENRY PERCY:\r","My lord, some two days since I saw the prince,\r","And told him of those triumphs held at Oxford.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","And what said the gallant?\r","\r","HENRY PERCY:\r","His answer was, he would unto the stews,\r","And from the common'st creature pluck a glove,\r","And wear it as a favour; and with that\r","He would unhorse the lustiest challenger.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","As dissolute as desperate; yet through both\r","I see some sparks of better hope, which elder years\r","May happily bring forth. But who comes here?\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","Where is the king?\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","What means our cousin, that he stares and looks\r","So wildly?\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","God save your grace! I do beseech your majesty,\r","To have some conference with your grace alone.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Withdraw yourselves, and leave us here alone.\r","What is the matter with our cousin now?\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","For ever may my knees grow to the earth,\r","My tongue cleave to my roof within my mouth\r","Unless a pardon ere I rise or speak.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Intended or committed was this fault?\r","If on the first, how heinous e'er it be,\r","To win thy after-love I pardon thee.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","Then give me leave that I may turn the key,\r","That no man enter till my tale be done.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Have thy desire.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Villain, I'll make thee safe.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","Stay thy revengeful hand; thou hast no cause to fear.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","What is the matter, uncle? speak;\r","Recover breath; tell us how near is danger,\r","That we may arm us to encounter it.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Peruse this writing here, and thou shalt know\r","The treason that my haste forbids me show.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","Remember, as thou read'st, thy promise pass'd:\r","I do repent me; read not my name there\r","My heart is not confederate with my hand.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","It was, villain, ere thy hand did set it down.\r","I tore it from the traitor's bosom, king;\r","Fear, and not love, begets his penitence:\r","Forget to pity him, lest thy pity prove\r","A serpent that will sting thee to the heart.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","O heinous, strong and bold conspiracy!\r","O loyal father of a treacherous son!\r","Thou sheer, immaculate and silver fountain,\r","From when this stream through muddy passages\r","Hath held his current and defiled himself!\r","Thy overflow of good converts to bad,\r","And thy abundant goodness shall excuse\r","This deadly blot in thy digressing son.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","So shall my virtue be his vice's bawd;\r","And he shall spend mine honour with his shame,\r","As thriftless sons their scraping fathers' gold.\r","Mine honour lives when his dishonour dies,\r","Or my shamed life in his dishonour lies:\r","Thou kill'st me in his life; giving him breath,\r","The traitor lives, the true man's put to death.\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","What shrill-voiced suppliant makes this eager cry?\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","A woman, and thy aunt, great king; 'tis I.\r","Speak with me, pity me, open the door.\r","A beggar begs that never begg'd before.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Our scene is alter'd from a serious thing,\r","And now changed to 'The Beggar and the King.'\r","My dangerous cousin, let your mother in:\r","I know she is come to pray for your foul sin.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","If thou do pardon, whosoever pray,\r","More sins for this forgiveness prosper may.\r","This fester'd joint cut off, the rest rest sound;\r","This let alone will all the rest confound.\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","O king, believe not this hard-hearted man!\r","Love loving not itself none other can.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Thou frantic woman, what dost thou make here?\r","Shall thy old dugs once more a traitor rear?\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","Sweet York, be patient. Hear me, gentle liege.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Rise up, good aunt.\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","Not yet, I thee beseech:\r","For ever will I walk upon my knees,\r","And never see day that the happy sees,\r","Till thou give joy; until thou bid me joy,\r","By pardoning Rutland, my transgressing boy.\r","\r","DUKE OF AUMERLE:\r","Unto my mother's prayers I bend my knee.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Against them both my true joints bended be.\r","Ill mayst thou thrive, if thou grant any grace!\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","Pleads he in earnest? look upon his face;\r","His eyes do drop no tears, his prayers are in jest;\r","His words come from his mouth, ours from our breast:\r","He prays but faintly and would be denied;\r","We pray with heart and soul and all beside:\r","His weary joints would gladly rise, I know;\r","Our knees shall kneel till to the ground they grow:\r","His prayers are full of false hypocrisy;\r","Ours of true zeal and deep integrity.\r","Our prayers do out-pray his; then let them have\r","That mercy which true prayer ought to have.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Good aunt, stand up.\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","Nay, do not say, 'stand up;'\r","Say, 'pardon' first, and afterwards 'stand up.'\r","And if I were thy nurse, thy tongue to teach,\r","'Pardon' should be the first word of thy speech.\r","I never long'd to hear a word till now;\r","Say 'pardon,' king; let pity teach thee how:\r","The word is short, but not so short as sweet;\r","No word like 'pardon' for kings' mouths so meet.\r","\r","DUKE OF YORK:\r","Speak it in French, king; say, 'pardonne moi.'\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","Dost thou teach pardon pardon to destroy?\r","Ah, my sour husband, my hard-hearted lord,\r","That set'st the word itself against the word!\r","Speak 'pardon' as 'tis current in our land;\r","The chopping French we do not understand.\r","Thine eye begins to speak; set thy tongue there;\r","Or in thy piteous heart plant thou thine ear;\r","That hearing how our plaints and prayers do pierce,\r","Pity may move thee 'pardon' to rehearse.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Good aunt, stand up.\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","I do not sue to stand;\r","Pardon is all the suit I have in hand.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","I pardon him, as God shall pardon me.\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","O happy vantage of a kneeling knee!\r","Yet am I sick for fear: speak it again;\r","Twice saying 'pardon' doth not pardon twain,\r","But makes one pardon strong.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","With all my heart\r","I pardon him.\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","A god on earth thou art.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","But for our trusty brother-in-law and the abbot,\r","With all the rest of that consorted crew,\r","Destruction straight shall dog them at the heels.\r","Good uncle, help to order several powers\r","To Oxford, or where'er these traitors are:\r","They shall not live within this world, I swear,\r","But I will have them, if I once know where.\r","Uncle, farewell: and, cousin too, adieu:\r","Your mother well hath pray'd, and prove you true.\r","\r","DUCHESS OF YORK:\r","Come, my old son: I pray God make thee new.\r","\r","EXTON:\r","Didst thou not mark the king, what words he spake,\r","'Have I no friend will rid me of this living fear?'\r","Was it not so?\r","\r","Servant:\r","These were his very words.\r","\r","EXTON:\r","'Have I no friend?' quoth he: he spake it twice,\r","And urged it twice together, did he not?\r","\r","Servant:\r","He did.\r","\r","EXTON:\r","And speaking it, he wistly look'd on me,\r","And who should say, 'I would thou wert the man'\r","That would divorce this terror from my heart;'\r","Meaning the king at Pomfret. Come, let's go:\r","I am the king's friend, and will rid his foe.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","I have been studying how I may compare\r","This prison where I live unto the world:\r","And for because the world is populous\r","And here is not a creature but myself,\r","I cannot do it; yet I'll hammer it out.\r","My brain I'll prove the female to my soul,\r","My soul the father; and these two beget\r","A generation of still-breeding thoughts,\r","And these same thoughts people this little world,\r","In humours like the people of this world,\r","For no thought is contented. The better sort,\r","As thoughts of things divine, are intermix'd\r","With scruples and do set the word itself\r","Against the word:\r","As thus, 'Come, little ones,' and then again,\r","'It is as hard to come as for a camel\r","To thread the postern of a small needle's eye.'\r","Thoughts tending to ambition, they do plot\r","Unlikely wonders; how these vain weak nails\r","May tear a passage through the flinty ribs\r","Of this hard world, my ragged prison walls,\r","And, for they cannot, die in their own pride.\r","Thoughts tending to content flatter themselves\r","That they are not the first of fortune's slaves,\r","Nor shall not be the last; like silly beggars\r","Who sitting in the stocks refuge their shame,\r","That many have and others must sit there;\r","And in this thought they find a kind of ease,\r","Bearing their own misfortunes on the back\r","Of such as have before endured the like.\r","Thus play I in one person many people,\r","And none contented: sometimes am I king;\r","Then treasons make me wish myself a beggar,\r","And so I am: then crushing penury\r","Persuades me I was better when a king;\r","Then am I king'd again: and by and by\r","Think that I am unking'd by Bolingbroke,\r","And straight am nothing: but whate'er I be,\r","Nor I nor any man that but man is\r","With nothing shall be pleased, till he be eased\r","With being nothing. Music do I hear?\r","Ha, ha! keep time: how sour sweet music is,\r","When time is broke and no proportion kept!\r","So is it in the music of men's lives.\r","And here have I the daintiness of ear\r","To cheque time broke in a disorder'd string;\r","But for the concord of my state and time\r","Had not an ear to hear my true time broke.\r","I wasted time, and now doth time waste me;\r","For now hath time made me his numbering clock:\r","My thoughts are minutes; and with sighs they jar\r","Their watches on unto mine eyes, the outward watch,\r","Whereto my finger, like a dial's point,\r","Is pointing still, in cleansing them from tears.\r","Now sir, the sound that tells what hour it is\r","Are clamorous groans, which strike upon my heart,\r","Which is the bell: so sighs and tears and groans\r","Show minutes, times, and hours: but my time\r","Runs posting on in Bolingbroke's proud joy,\r","While I stand fooling here, his Jack o' the clock.\r","This music mads me; let it sound no more;\r","For though it have holp madmen to their wits,\r","In me it seems it will make wise men mad.\r","Yet blessing on his heart that gives it me!\r","For 'tis a sign of love; and love to Richard\r","Is a strange brooch in this all-hating world.\r","\r","Groom:\r","Hail, royal prince!\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Thanks, noble peer;\r","The cheapest of us is ten groats too dear.\r","What art thou? and how comest thou hither,\r","Where no man never comes but that sad dog\r","That brings me food to make misfortune live?\r","\r","Groom:\r","I was a poor groom of thy stable, king,\r","When thou wert king; who, travelling towards York,\r","With much ado at length have gotten leave\r","To look upon my sometimes royal master's face.\r","O, how it yearn'd my heart when I beheld\r","In London streets, that coronation-day,\r","When Bolingbroke rode on roan Barbary,\r","That horse that thou so often hast bestrid,\r","That horse that I so carefully have dress'd!\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Rode he on Barbary? Tell me, gentle friend,\r","How went he under him?\r","\r","Groom:\r","So proudly as if he disdain'd the ground.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","So proud that Bolingbroke was on his back!\r","That jade hath eat bread from my royal hand;\r","This hand hath made him proud with clapping him.\r","Would he not stumble? would he not fall down,\r","Since pride must have a fall, and break the neck\r","Of that proud man that did usurp his back?\r","Forgiveness, horse! why do I rail on thee,\r","Since thou, created to be awed by man,\r","Wast born to bear? I was not made a horse;\r","And yet I bear a burthen like an ass,\r","Spurr'd, gall'd and tired by jouncing Bolingbroke.\r","\r","Keeper:\r","Fellow, give place; here is no longer stay.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","If thou love me, 'tis time thou wert away.\r","\r","Groom:\r","What my tongue dares not, that my heart shall say.\r","\r","Keeper:\r","My lord, will't please you to fall to?\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","Taste of it first, as thou art wont to do.\r","\r","Keeper:\r","My lord, I dare not: Sir Pierce of Exton, who\r","lately came from the king, commands the contrary.\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","The devil take Henry of Lancaster and thee!\r","Patience is stale, and I am weary of it.\r","\r","Keeper:\r","Help, help, help!\r","\r","KING RICHARD II:\r","How now! what means death in this rude assault?\r","Villain, thy own hand yields thy death's instrument.\r","Go thou, and fill another room in hell.\r","That hand shall burn in never-quenching fire\r","That staggers thus my person. Exton, thy fierce hand\r","Hath with the king's blood stain'd the king's own land.\r","Mount, mount, my soul! thy seat is up on high;\r","Whilst my gross flesh sinks downward, here to die.\r","\r","EXTON:\r","As full of valour as of royal blood:\r","Both have I spill'd; O would the deed were good!\r","For now the devil, that told me I did well,\r","Says that this deed is chronicled in hell.\r","This dead king to the living king I'll bear\r","Take hence the rest, and give them burial here.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Kind uncle York, the latest news we hear\r","Is that the rebels have consumed with fire\r","Our town of Cicester in Gloucestershire;\r","But whether they be ta'en or slain we hear not.\r","Welcome, my lord what is the news?\r","\r","NORTHUMBERLAND:\r","First, to thy sacred state wish I all happiness.\r","The next news is, I have to London sent\r","The heads of Oxford, Salisbury, Blunt, and Kent:\r","The manner of their taking may appear\r","At large discoursed in this paper here.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","We thank thee, gentle Percy, for thy pains;\r","And to thy worth will add right worthy gains.\r","\r","LORD FITZWATER:\r","My lord, I have from Oxford sent to London\r","The heads of Brocas and Sir Bennet Seely,\r","Two of the dangerous consorted traitors\r","That sought at Oxford thy dire overthrow.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Thy pains, Fitzwater, shall not be forgot;\r","Right noble is thy merit, well I wot.\r","\r","HENRY PERCY:\r","The grand conspirator, Abbot of Westminster,\r","With clog of conscience and sour melancholy\r","Hath yielded up his body to the grave;\r","But here is Carlisle living, to abide\r","Thy kingly doom and sentence of his pride.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Carlisle, this is your doom:\r","Choose out some secret place, some reverend room,\r","More than thou hast, and with it joy thy life;\r","So as thou livest in peace, die free from strife:\r","For though mine enemy thou hast ever been,\r","High sparks of honour in thee have I seen.\r","\r","EXTON:\r","Great king, within this coffin I present\r","Thy buried fear: herein all breathless lies\r","The mightiest of thy greatest enemies,\r","Richard of Bordeaux, by me hither brought.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","Exton, I thank thee not; for thou hast wrought\r","A deed of slander with thy fatal hand\r","Upon my head and all this famous land.\r","\r","EXTON:\r","From your own mouth, my lord, did I this deed.\r","\r","HENRY BOLINGBROKE:\r","They love not poison that do poison need,\r","Nor do I thee: though I did wish him dead,\r","I hate the murderer, love him murdered.\r","The guilt of conscience take thou for thy labour,\r","But neither my good word nor princely favour:\r","With Cain go wander through shades of night,\r","And never show thy head by day nor light.\r","Lords, I protest, my soul is full of woe,\r","That blood should sprinkle me to make me grow:\r","Come, mourn with me for that I do lament,\r","And put on sullen black incontinent:\r","I'll make a voyage to the Holy Land,\r","To wash this blood off from my guilty hand:\r","March sadly after; grace my mournings here;\r","In weeping after this untimely bier.\r","\r","\r","SAMPSON:\r","Gregory, o' my word, we'll not carry coals.\r","\r","GREGORY:\r","No, for then we should be colliers.\r","\r","SAMPSON:\r","I mean, an we be in choler, we'll draw.\r","\r","GREGORY:\r","Ay, while you live, draw your neck out o' the collar.\r","\r","SAMPSON:\r","I strike quickly, being moved.\r","\r","GREGORY:\r","But thou art not quickly moved to strike.\r","\r","SAMPSON:\r","A dog of the house of Montague moves me.\r","\r","GREGORY:\r","To move is to stir; and to be valiant is to stand:\r","therefore, if thou art moved, thou runn'st away.\r","\r","SAMPSON:\r","A dog of that house shall move me to stand: I will\r","take the wall of any man or maid of Montague's.\r","\r","GREGORY:\r","That shows thee a weak slave; for the weakest goes\r","to the wall.\r","\r","SAMPSON:\r","True; and therefore women, being the weaker vessels,\r","are ever thrust to the wall: therefore I will push\r","Montague's men from the wall, and thrust his maids\r","to the wall.\r","\r","GREGORY:\r","The quarrel is between our masters and us their men.\r","\r","SAMPSON:\r","'Tis all one, I will show myself a tyrant: when I\r","have fought with the men, I will be cruel with the\r","maids, and cut off their heads.\r","\r","GREGORY:\r","The heads of the maids?\r","\r","SAMPSON:\r","Ay, the heads of the maids, or their maidenheads;\r","take it in what sense thou wilt.\r","\r","GREGORY:\r","They must take it in sense that feel it.\r","\r","SAMPSON:\r","Me they shall feel while I am able to stand: and\r","'tis known I am a pretty piece of flesh.\r","\r","GREGORY:\r","'Tis well thou art not fish; if thou hadst, thou\r","hadst been poor John. Draw thy tool! here comes\r","two of the house of the Montagues.\r","\r","SAMPSON:\r","My naked weapon is out: quarrel, I will back thee.\r","\r","GREGORY:\r","How! turn thy back and run?\r","\r","SAMPSON:\r","Fear me not.\r","\r","GREGORY:\r","No, marry; I fear thee!\r","\r","SAMPSON:\r","Let us take the law of our sides; let them begin.\r","\r","GREGORY:\r","I will frown as I pass by, and let them take it as\r","they list.\r","\r","SAMPSON:\r","Nay, as they dare. I will bite my thumb at them;\r","which is a disgrace to them, if they bear it.\r","\r","ABRAHAM:\r","Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?\r","\r","SAMPSON:\r","I do bite my thumb, sir.\r","\r","ABRAHAM:\r","Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?\r","\r","SAMPSON:\r","\r","GREGORY:\r","No.\r","\r","SAMPSON:\r","No, sir, I do not bite my thumb at you, sir, but I\r","bite my thumb, sir.\r","\r","GREGORY:\r","Do you quarrel, sir?\r","\r","ABRAHAM:\r","Quarrel sir! no, sir.\r","\r","SAMPSON:\r","If you do, sir, I am for you: I serve as good a man as you.\r","\r","ABRAHAM:\r","No better.\r","\r","SAMPSON:\r","Well, sir.\r","\r","GREGORY:\r","Say 'better:' here comes one of my master's kinsmen.\r","\r","SAMPSON:\r","Yes, better, sir.\r","\r","ABRAHAM:\r","You lie.\r","\r","SAMPSON:\r","Draw, if you be men. Gregory, remember thy swashing blow.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","Part, fools!\r","Put up your swords; you know not what you do.\r","\r","TYBALT:\r","What, art thou drawn among these heartless hinds?\r","Turn thee, Benvolio, look upon thy death.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","I do but keep the peace: put up thy sword,\r","Or manage it to part these men with me.\r","\r","TYBALT:\r","What, drawn, and talk of peace! I hate the word,\r","As I hate hell, all Montagues, and thee:\r","Have at thee, coward!\r","\r","First Citizen:\r","Clubs, bills, and partisans! strike! beat them down!\r","Down with the Capulets! down with the Montagues!\r","\r","CAPULET:\r","What noise is this? Give me my long sword, ho!\r","\r","LADY CAPULET:\r","A crutch, a crutch! why call you for a sword?\r","\r","CAPULET:\r","My sword, I say! Old Montague is come,\r","And flourishes his blade in spite of me.\r","\r","MONTAGUE:\r","Thou villain Capulet,--Hold me not, let me go.\r","\r","LADY MONTAGUE:\r","Thou shalt not stir a foot to seek a foe.\r","\r","PRINCE:\r","Rebellious subjects, enemies to peace,\r","Profaners of this neighbour-stained steel,--\r","Will they not hear? What, ho! you men, you beasts,\r","That quench the fire of your pernicious rage\r","With purple fountains issuing from your veins,\r","On pain of torture, from those bloody hands\r","Throw your mistemper'd weapons to the ground,\r","And hear the sentence of your moved prince.\r","Three civil brawls, bred of an airy word,\r","By thee, old Capulet, and Montague,\r","Have thrice disturb'd the quiet of our streets,\r","And made Verona's ancient citizens\r","Cast by their grave beseeming ornaments,\r","To wield old partisans, in hands as old,\r","Canker'd with peace, to part your canker'd hate:\r","If ever you disturb our streets again,\r","Your lives shall pay the forfeit of the peace.\r","For this time, all the rest depart away:\r","You Capulet; shall go along with me:\r","And, Montague, come you this afternoon,\r","To know our further pleasure in this case,\r","To old Free-town, our common judgment-place.\r","Once more, on pain of death, all men depart.\r","\r","MONTAGUE:\r","Who set this ancient quarrel new abroach?\r","Speak, nephew, were you by when it began?\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","Here were the servants of your adversary,\r","And yours, close fighting ere I did approach:\r","I drew to part them: in the instant came\r","The fiery Tybalt, with his sword prepared,\r","Which, as he breathed defiance to my ears,\r","He swung about his head and cut the winds,\r","Who nothing hurt withal hiss'd him in scorn:\r","While we were interchanging thrusts and blows,\r","Came more and more and fought on part and part,\r","Till the prince came, who parted either part.\r","\r","LADY MONTAGUE:\r","O, where is Romeo? saw you him to-day?\r","Right glad I am he was not at this fray.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","Madam, an hour before the worshipp'd sun\r","Peer'd forth the golden window of the east,\r","A troubled mind drave me to walk abroad;\r","Where, underneath the grove of sycamore\r","That westward rooteth from the city's side,\r","So early walking did I see your son:\r","Towards him I made, but he was ware of me\r","And stole into the covert of the wood:\r","I, measuring his affections by my own,\r","That most are busied when they're most alone,\r","Pursued my humour not pursuing his,\r","And gladly shunn'd who gladly fled from me.\r","\r","MONTAGUE:\r","Many a morning hath he there been seen,\r","With tears augmenting the fresh morning dew.\r","Adding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs;\r","But all so soon as the all-cheering sun\r","Should in the furthest east begin to draw\r","The shady curtains from Aurora's bed,\r","Away from the light steals home my heavy son,\r","And private in his chamber pens himself,\r","Shuts up his windows, locks far daylight out\r","And makes himself an artificial night:\r","Black and portentous must this humour prove,\r","Unless good counsel may the cause remove.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","My noble uncle, do you know the cause?\r","\r","MONTAGUE:\r","I neither know it nor can learn of him.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","Have you importuned him by any means?\r","\r","MONTAGUE:\r","Both by myself and many other friends:\r","But he, his own affections' counsellor,\r","Is to himself--I will not say how true--\r","But to himself so secret and so close,\r","So far from sounding and discovery,\r","As is the bud bit with an envious worm,\r","Ere he can spread his sweet leaves to the air,\r","Or dedicate his beauty to the sun.\r","Could we but learn from whence his sorrows grow.\r","We would as willingly give cure as know.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","See, where he comes: so please you, step aside;\r","I'll know his grievance, or be much denied.\r","\r","MONTAGUE:\r","I would thou wert so happy by thy stay,\r","To hear true shrift. Come, madam, let's away.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","Good-morrow, cousin.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Is the day so young?\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","But new struck nine.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Ay me! sad hours seem long.\r","Was that my father that went hence so fast?\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","It was. What sadness lengthens Romeo's hours?\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Not having that, which, having, makes them short.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","In love?\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Out--\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","Of love?\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Out of her favour, where I am in love.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","Alas, that love, so gentle in his view,\r","Should be so tyrannous and rough in proof!\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Alas, that love, whose view is muffled still,\r","Should, without eyes, see pathways to his will!\r","Where shall we dine? O me! What fray was here?\r","Yet tell me not, for I have heard it all.\r","Here's much to do with hate, but more with love.\r","Why, then, O brawling love! O loving hate!\r","O any thing, of nothing first create!\r","O heavy lightness! serious vanity!\r","Mis-shapen chaos of well-seeming forms!\r","Feather of lead, bright smoke, cold fire,\r","sick health!\r","Still-waking sleep, that is not what it is!\r","This love feel I, that feel no love in this.\r","Dost thou not laugh?\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","No, coz, I rather weep.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Good heart, at what?\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","At thy good heart's oppression.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Why, such is love's transgression.\r","Griefs of mine own lie heavy in my breast,\r","Which thou wilt propagate, to have it prest\r","With more of thine: this love that thou hast shown\r","Doth add more grief to too much of mine own.\r","Love is a smoke raised with the fume of sighs;\r","Being purged, a fire sparkling in lovers' eyes;\r","Being vex'd a sea nourish'd with lovers' tears:\r","What is it else? a madness most discreet,\r","A choking gall and a preserving sweet.\r","Farewell, my coz.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","Soft! I will go along;\r","An if you leave me so, you do me wrong.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Tut, I have lost myself; I am not here;\r","This is not Romeo, he's some other where.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","Tell me in sadness, who is that you love.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","What, shall I groan and tell thee?\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","Groan! why, no.\r","But sadly tell me who.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Bid a sick man in sadness make his will:\r","Ah, word ill urged to one that is so ill!\r","In sadness, cousin, I do love a woman.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","I aim'd so near, when I supposed you loved.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","A right good mark-man! And she's fair I love.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","A right fair mark, fair coz, is soonest hit.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Well, in that hit you miss: she'll not be hit\r","With Cupid's arrow; she hath Dian's wit;\r","And, in strong proof of chastity well arm'd,\r","From love's weak childish bow she lives unharm'd.\r","She will not stay the siege of loving terms,\r","Nor bide the encounter of assailing eyes,\r","Nor ope her lap to saint-seducing gold:\r","O, she is rich in beauty, only poor,\r","That when she dies with beauty dies her store.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","Then she hath sworn that she will still live chaste?\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","She hath, and in that sparing makes huge waste,\r","For beauty starved with her severity\r","Cuts beauty off from all posterity.\r","She is too fair, too wise, wisely too fair,\r","To merit bliss by making me despair:\r","She hath forsworn to love, and in that vow\r","Do I live dead that live to tell it now.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","Be ruled by me, forget to think of her.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","O, teach me how I should forget to think.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","By giving liberty unto thine eyes;\r","Examine other beauties.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","'Tis the way\r","To call hers exquisite, in question more:\r","These happy masks that kiss fair ladies' brows\r","Being black put us in mind they hide the fair;\r","He that is strucken blind cannot forget\r","The precious treasure of his eyesight lost:\r","Show me a mistress that is passing fair,\r","What doth her beauty serve, but as a note\r","Where I may read who pass'd that passing fair?\r","Farewell: thou canst not teach me to forget.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","I'll pay that doctrine, or else die in debt.\r","\r","CAPULET:\r","But Montague is bound as well as I,\r","In penalty alike; and 'tis not hard, I think,\r","For men so old as we to keep the peace.\r","\r","PARIS:\r","Of honourable reckoning are you both;\r","And pity 'tis you lived at odds so long.\r","But now, my lord, what say you to my suit?\r","\r","CAPULET:\r","But saying o'er what I have said before:\r","My child is yet a stranger in the world;\r","She hath not seen the change of fourteen years,\r","Let two more summers wither in their pride,\r","Ere we may think her ripe to be a bride.\r","\r","PARIS:\r","Younger than she are happy mothers made.\r","\r","CAPULET:\r","And too soon marr'd are those so early made.\r","The earth hath swallow'd all my hopes but she,\r","She is the hopeful lady of my earth:\r","But woo her, gentle Paris, get her heart,\r","My will to her consent is but a part;\r","An she agree, within her scope of choice\r","Lies my consent and fair according voice.\r","This night I hold an old accustom'd feast,\r","Whereto I have invited many a guest,\r","Such as I love; and you, among the store,\r","One more, most welcome, makes my number more.\r","At my poor house look to behold this night\r","Earth-treading stars that make dark heaven light:\r","Such comfort as do lusty young men feel\r","When well-apparell'd April on the heel\r","Of limping winter treads, even such delight\r","Among fresh female buds shall you this night\r","Inherit at my house; hear all, all see,\r","And like her most whose merit most shall be:\r","Which on more view, of many mine being one\r","May stand in number, though in reckoning none,\r","Come, go with me.\r","Go, sirrah, trudge about\r","Through fair Verona; find those persons out\r","Whose names are written there, and to them say,\r","My house and welcome on their pleasure stay.\r","\r","Servant:\r","Find them out whose names are written here! It is\r","written, that the shoemaker should meddle with his\r","yard, and the tailor with his last, the fisher with\r","his pencil, and the painter with his nets; but I am\r","sent to find those persons whose names are here\r","writ, and can never find what names the writing\r","person hath here writ. I must to the learned.--In good time.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","Tut, man, one fire burns out another's burning,\r","One pain is lessen'd by another's anguish;\r","Turn giddy, and be holp by backward turning;\r","One desperate grief cures with another's languish:\r","Take thou some new infection to thy eye,\r","And the rank poison of the old will die.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Your plaintain-leaf is excellent for that.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","For what, I pray thee?\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","For your broken shin.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","Why, Romeo, art thou mad?\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Not mad, but bound more than a mad-man is;\r","Shut up in prison, kept without my food,\r","Whipp'd and tormented and--God-den, good fellow.\r","\r","Servant:\r","God gi' god-den. I pray, sir, can you read?\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Ay, mine own fortune in my misery.\r","\r","Servant:\r","Perhaps you have learned it without book: but, I\r","pray, can you read any thing you see?\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Ay, if I know the letters and the language.\r","\r","Servant:\r","Ye say honestly: rest you merry!\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Stay, fellow; I can read.\r","'Signior Martino and his wife and daughters;\r","County Anselme and his beauteous sisters; the lady\r","widow of Vitravio; Signior Placentio and his lovely\r","nieces; Mercutio and his brother Valentine; mine\r","uncle Capulet, his wife and daughters; my fair niece\r","Rosaline; Livia; Signior Valentio and his cousin\r","Tybalt, Lucio and the lively Helena.' A fair\r","assembly: whither should they come?\r","\r","Servant:\r","Up.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Whither?\r","\r","Servant:\r","To supper; to our house.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Whose house?\r","\r","Servant:\r","My master's.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Indeed, I should have ask'd you that before.\r","\r","Servant:\r","Now I'll tell you without asking: my master is the\r","great rich Capulet; and if you be not of the house\r","of Montagues, I pray, come and crush a cup of wine.\r","Rest you merry!\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","At this same ancient feast of Capulet's\r","Sups the fair Rosaline whom thou so lovest,\r","With all the admired beauties of Verona:\r","Go thither; and, with unattainted eye,\r","Compare her face with some that I shall show,\r","And I will make thee think thy swan a crow.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","When the devout religion of mine eye\r","Maintains such falsehood, then turn tears to fires;\r","And these, who often drown'd could never die,\r","Transparent heretics, be burnt for liars!\r","One fairer than my love! the all-seeing sun\r","Ne'er saw her match since first the world begun.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","Tut, you saw her fair, none else being by,\r","Herself poised with herself in either eye:\r","But in that crystal scales let there be weigh'd\r","Your lady's love against some other maid\r","That I will show you shining at this feast,\r","And she shall scant show well that now shows best.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","I'll go along, no such sight to be shown,\r","But to rejoice in splendor of mine own.\r","\r","LADY CAPULET:\r","Nurse, where's my daughter? call her forth to me.\r","\r","Nurse:\r","Now, by my maidenhead, at twelve year old,\r","I bade her come. What, lamb! what, ladybird!\r","God forbid! Where's this girl? What, Juliet!\r","\r","JULIET:\r","How now! who calls?\r","\r","Nurse:\r","Your mother.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","Madam, I am here.\r","What is your will?\r","\r","LADY CAPULET:\r","This is the matter:--Nurse, give leave awhile,\r","We must talk in secret:--nurse, come back again;\r","I have remember'd me, thou's hear our counsel.\r","Thou know'st my daughter's of a pretty age.\r","\r","Nurse:\r","Faith, I can tell her age unto an hour.\r","\r","LADY CAPULET:\r","She's not fourteen.\r","\r","Nurse:\r","I'll lay fourteen of my teeth,--\r","And yet, to my teeth be it spoken, I have but four--\r","She is not fourteen. How long is it now\r","To Lammas-tide?\r","\r","LADY CAPULET:\r","A fortnight and odd days.\r","\r","Nurse:\r","Even or odd, of all days in the year,\r","Come Lammas-eve at night shall she be fourteen.\r","Susan and she--God rest all Christian souls!--\r","Were of an age: well, Susan is with God;\r","She was too good for me: but, as I said,\r","On Lammas-eve at night shall she be fourteen;\r","That shall she, marry; I remember it well.\r","'Tis since the earthquake now eleven years;\r","And she was wean'd,--I never shall forget it,--\r","Of all the days of the year, upon that day:\r","For I had then laid wormwood to my dug,\r","Sitting in the sun under the dove-house wall;\r","My lord and you were then at Mantua:--\r","Nay, I do bear a brain:--but, as I said,\r","When it did taste the wormwood on the nipple\r","Of my dug and felt it bitter, pretty fool,\r","To see it tetchy and fall out with the dug!\r","Shake quoth the dove-house: 'twas no need, I trow,\r","To bid me trudge:\r","And since that time it is eleven years;\r","For then she could stand alone; nay, by the rood,\r","She could have run and waddled all about;\r","For even the day before, she broke her brow:\r","And then my husband--God be with his soul!\r","A' was a merry man--took up the child:\r","'Yea,' quoth he, 'dost thou fall upon thy face?\r","Thou wilt fall backward when thou hast more wit;\r","Wilt thou not, Jule?' and, by my holidame,\r","The pretty wretch left crying and said 'Ay.'\r","To see, now, how a jest shall come about!\r","I warrant, an I should live a thousand years,\r","I never should forget it: 'Wilt thou not, Jule?' quoth he;\r","And, pretty fool, it stinted and said 'Ay.'\r","\r","LADY CAPULET:\r","Enough of this; I pray thee, hold thy peace.\r","\r","Nurse:\r","Yes, madam: yet I cannot choose but laugh,\r","To think it should leave crying and say 'Ay.'\r","And yet, I warrant, it had upon its brow\r","A bump as big as a young cockerel's stone;\r","A parlous knock; and it cried bitterly:\r","'Yea,' quoth my husband,'fall'st upon thy face?\r","Thou wilt fall backward when thou comest to age;\r","Wilt thou not, Jule?' it stinted and said 'Ay.'\r","\r","JULIET:\r","And stint thou too, I pray thee, nurse, say I.\r","\r","Nurse:\r","Peace, I have done. God mark thee to his grace!\r","Thou wast the prettiest babe that e'er I nursed:\r","An I might live to see thee married once,\r","I have my wish.\r","\r","LADY CAPULET:\r","Marry, that 'marry' is the very theme\r","I came to talk of. Tell me, daughter Juliet,\r","How stands your disposition to be married?\r","\r","JULIET:\r","It is an honour that I dream not of.\r","\r","Nurse:\r","An honour! were not I thine only nurse,\r","I would say thou hadst suck'd wisdom from thy teat.\r","\r","LADY CAPULET:\r","Well, think of marriage now; younger than you,\r","Here in Verona, ladies of esteem,\r","Are made already mothers: by my count,\r","I was your mother much upon these years\r","That you are now a maid. Thus then in brief:\r","The valiant Paris seeks you for his love.\r","\r","Nurse:\r","A man, young lady! lady, such a man\r","As all the world--why, he's a man of wax.\r","\r","LADY CAPULET:\r","Verona's summer hath not such a flower.\r","\r","Nurse:\r","Nay, he's a flower; in faith, a very flower.\r","\r","LADY CAPULET:\r","What say you? can you love the gentleman?\r","This night you shall behold him at our feast;\r","Read o'er the volume of young Paris' face,\r","And find delight writ there with beauty's pen;\r","Examine every married lineament,\r","And see how one another lends content\r","And what obscured in this fair volume lies\r","Find written in the margent of his eyes.\r","This precious book of love, this unbound lover,\r","To beautify him, only lacks a cover:\r","The fish lives in the sea, and 'tis much pride\r","For fair without the fair within to hide:\r","That book in many's eyes doth share the glory,\r","That in gold clasps locks in the golden story;\r","So shall you share all that he doth possess,\r","By having him, making yourself no less.\r","\r","Nurse:\r","No less! nay, bigger; women grow by men.\r","\r","LADY CAPULET:\r","Speak briefly, can you like of Paris' love?\r","\r","JULIET:\r","I'll look to like, if looking liking move:\r","But no more deep will I endart mine eye\r","Than your consent gives strength to make it fly.\r","\r","Servant:\r","Madam, the guests are come, supper served up, you\r","called, my young lady asked for, the nurse cursed in\r","the pantry, and every thing in extremity. I must\r","hence to wait; I beseech you, follow straight.\r","\r","LADY CAPULET:\r","We follow thee.\r","Juliet, the county stays.\r","\r","Nurse:\r","Go, girl, seek happy nights to happy days.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","What, shall this speech be spoke for our excuse?\r","Or shall we on without a apology?\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","The date is out of such prolixity:\r","We'll have no Cupid hoodwink'd with a scarf,\r","Bearing a Tartar's painted bow of lath,\r","Scaring the ladies like a crow-keeper;\r","Nor no without-book prologue, faintly spoke\r","After the prompter, for our entrance:\r","But let them measure us by what they will;\r","We'll measure them a measure, and be gone.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Give me a torch: I am not for this ambling;\r","Being but heavy, I will bear the light.\r","\r","MERCUTIO:\r","Nay, gentle Romeo, we must have you dance.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Not I, believe me: you have dancing shoes\r","With nimble soles: I have a soul of lead\r","So stakes me to the ground I cannot move.\r","\r","MERCUTIO:\r","You are a lover; borrow Cupid's wings,\r","And soar with them above a common bound.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","I am too sore enpierced with his shaft\r","To soar with his light feathers, and so bound,\r","I cannot bound a pitch above dull woe:\r","Under love's heavy burden do I sink.\r","\r","MERCUTIO:\r","And, to sink in it, should you burden love;\r","Too great oppression for a tender thing.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Is love a tender thing? it is too rough,\r","Too rude, too boisterous, and it pricks like thorn.\r","\r","MERCUTIO:\r","If love be rough with you, be rough with love;\r","Prick love for pricking, and you beat love down.\r","Give me a case to put my visage in:\r","A visor for a visor! what care I\r","What curious eye doth quote deformities?\r","Here are the beetle brows shall blush for me.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","Come, knock and enter; and no sooner in,\r","But every man betake him to his legs.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","A torch for me: let wantons light of heart\r","Tickle the senseless rushes with their heels,\r","For I am proverb'd with a grandsire phrase;\r","I'll be a candle-holder, and look on.\r","The game was ne'er so fair, and I am done.\r","\r","MERCUTIO:\r","Tut, dun's the mouse, the constable's own word:\r","If thou art dun, we'll draw thee from the mire\r","Of this sir-reverence love, wherein thou stick'st\r","Up to the ears. Come, we burn daylight, ho!\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Nay, that's not so.\r","\r","MERCUTIO:\r","I mean, sir, in delay\r","We waste our lights in vain, like lamps by day.\r","Take our good meaning, for our judgment sits\r","Five times in that ere once in our five wits.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","And we mean well in going to this mask;\r","But 'tis no wit to go.\r","\r","MERCUTIO:\r","Why, may one ask?\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","I dream'd a dream to-night.\r","\r","MERCUTIO:\r","And so did I.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Well, what was yours?\r","\r","MERCUTIO:\r","That dreamers often lie.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","In bed asleep, while they do dream things true.\r","\r","MERCUTIO:\r","O, then, I see Queen Mab hath been with you.\r","She is the fairies' midwife, and she comes\r","In shape no bigger than an agate-stone\r","On the fore-finger of an alderman,\r","Drawn with a team of little atomies\r","Athwart men's noses as they lie asleep;\r","Her wagon-spokes made of long spiders' legs,\r","The cover of the wings of grasshoppers,\r","The traces of the smallest spider's web,\r","The collars of the moonshine's watery beams,\r","Her whip of cricket's bone, the lash of film,\r","Her wagoner a small grey-coated gnat,\r","Not so big as a round little worm\r","Prick'd from the lazy finger of a maid;\r","Her chariot is an empty hazel-nut\r","Made by the joiner squirrel or old grub,\r","Time out o' mind the fairies' coachmakers.\r","And in this state she gallops night by night\r","Through lovers' brains, and then they dream of love;\r","O'er courtiers' knees, that dream on court'sies straight,\r","O'er lawyers' fingers, who straight dream on fees,\r","O'er ladies ' lips, who straight on kisses dream,\r","Which oft the angry Mab with blisters plagues,\r","Because their breaths with sweetmeats tainted are:\r","Sometime she gallops o'er a courtier's nose,\r","And then dreams he of smelling out a suit;\r","And sometime comes she with a tithe-pig's tail\r","Tickling a parson's nose as a' lies asleep,\r","Then dreams, he of another benefice:\r","Sometime she driveth o'er a soldier's neck,\r","And then dreams he of cutting foreign throats,\r","Of breaches, ambuscadoes, Spanish blades,\r","Of healths five-fathom deep; and then anon\r","Drums in his ear, at which he starts and wakes,\r","And being thus frighted swears a prayer or two\r","And sleeps again. This is that very Mab\r","That plats the manes of horses in the night,\r","And bakes the elflocks in foul sluttish hairs,\r","Which once untangled, much misfortune bodes:\r","This is the hag, when maids lie on their backs,\r","That presses them and learns them first to bear,\r","Making them women of good carriage:\r","This is she--\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Peace, peace, Mercutio, peace!\r","Thou talk'st of nothing.\r","\r","MERCUTIO:\r","True, I talk of dreams,\r","Which are the children of an idle brain,\r","Begot of nothing but vain fantasy,\r","Which is as thin of substance as the air\r","And more inconstant than the wind, who wooes\r","Even now the frozen bosom of the north,\r","And, being anger'd, puffs away from thence,\r","Turning his face to the dew-dropping south.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","This wind, you talk of, blows us from ourselves;\r","Supper is done, and we shall come too late.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","I fear, too early: for my mind misgives\r","Some consequence yet hanging in the stars\r","Shall bitterly begin his fearful date\r","With this night's revels and expire the term\r","Of a despised life closed in my breast\r","By some vile forfeit of untimely death.\r","But He, that hath the steerage of my course,\r","Direct my sail! On, lusty gentlemen.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","Strike, drum.\r","\r","First Servant:\r","Where's Potpan, that he helps not to take away? He\r","shift a trencher? he scrape a trencher!\r","\r","Second Servant:\r","When good manners shall lie all in one or two men's\r","hands and they unwashed too, 'tis a foul thing.\r","\r","First Servant:\r","Away with the joint-stools, remove the\r","court-cupboard, look to the plate. Good thou, save\r","me a piece of marchpane; and, as thou lovest me, let\r","the porter let in Susan Grindstone and Nell.\r","Antony, and Potpan!\r","\r","Second Servant:\r","Ay, boy, ready.\r","\r","First Servant:\r","You are looked for and called for, asked for and\r","sought for, in the great chamber.\r","\r","Second Servant:\r","We cannot be here and there too. Cheerly, boys; be\r","brisk awhile, and the longer liver take all.\r","\r","CAPULET:\r","Welcome, gentlemen! ladies that have their toes\r","Unplagued with corns will have a bout with you.\r","Ah ha, my mistresses! which of you all\r","Will now deny to dance? she that makes dainty,\r","She, I'll swear, hath corns; am I come near ye now?\r","Welcome, gentlemen! I have seen the day\r","That I have worn a visor and could tell\r","A whispering tale in a fair lady's ear,\r","Such as would please: 'tis gone, 'tis gone, 'tis gone:\r","You are welcome, gentlemen! come, musicians, play.\r","A hall, a hall! give room! and foot it, girls.\r","More light, you knaves; and turn the tables up,\r","And quench the fire, the room is grown too hot.\r","Ah, sirrah, this unlook'd-for sport comes well.\r","Nay, sit, nay, sit, good cousin Capulet;\r","For you and I are past our dancing days:\r","How long is't now since last yourself and I\r","Were in a mask?\r","\r","Second Capulet:\r","By'r lady, thirty years.\r","\r","CAPULET:\r","What, man! 'tis not so much, 'tis not so much:\r","'Tis since the nuptials of Lucentio,\r","Come pentecost as quickly as it will,\r","Some five and twenty years; and then we mask'd.\r","\r","Second Capulet:\r","'Tis more, 'tis more, his son is elder, sir;\r","His son is thirty.\r","\r","CAPULET:\r","Will you tell me that?\r","His son was but a ward two years ago.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","\r","Servant:\r","I know not, sir.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","O, she doth teach the torches to burn bright!\r","It seems she hangs upon the cheek of night\r","Like a rich jewel in an Ethiope's ear;\r","Beauty too rich for use, for earth too dear!\r","So shows a snowy dove trooping with crows,\r","As yonder lady o'er her fellows shows.\r","The measure done, I'll watch her place of stand,\r","And, touching hers, make blessed my rude hand.\r","Did my heart love till now? forswear it, sight!\r","For I ne'er saw true beauty till this night.\r","\r","TYBALT:\r","This, by his voice, should be a Montague.\r","Fetch me my rapier, boy. What dares the slave\r","Come hither, cover'd with an antic face,\r","To fleer and scorn at our solemnity?\r","Now, by the stock and honour of my kin,\r","To strike him dead, I hold it not a sin.\r","\r","CAPULET:\r","Why, how now, kinsman! wherefore storm you so?\r","\r","TYBALT:\r","Uncle, this is a Montague, our foe,\r","A villain that is hither come in spite,\r","To scorn at our solemnity this night.\r","\r","CAPULET:\r","Young Romeo is it?\r","\r","TYBALT:\r","'Tis he, that villain Romeo.\r","\r","CAPULET:\r","Content thee, gentle coz, let him alone;\r","He bears him like a portly gentleman;\r","And, to say truth, Verona brags of him\r","To be a virtuous and well-govern'd youth:\r","I would not for the wealth of all the town\r","Here in my house do him disparagement:\r","Therefore be patient, take no note of him:\r","It is my will, the which if thou respect,\r","Show a fair presence and put off these frowns,\r","And ill-beseeming semblance for a feast.\r","\r","TYBALT:\r","It fits, when such a villain is a guest:\r","I'll not endure him.\r","\r","CAPULET:\r","He shall be endured:\r","What, goodman boy! I say, he shall: go to;\r","Am I the master here, or you? go to.\r","You'll not endure him! God shall mend my soul!\r","You'll make a mutiny among my guests!\r","You will set cock-a-hoop! you'll be the man!\r","\r","TYBALT:\r","Why, uncle, 'tis a shame.\r","\r","CAPULET:\r","Go to, go to;\r","You are a saucy boy: is't so, indeed?\r","This trick may chance to scathe you, I know what:\r","You must contrary me! marry, 'tis time.\r","Well said, my hearts! You are a princox; go:\r","Be quiet, or--More light, more light! For shame!\r","I'll make you quiet. What, cheerly, my hearts!\r","\r","TYBALT:\r","Patience perforce with wilful choler meeting\r","Makes my flesh tremble in their different greeting.\r","I will withdraw: but this intrusion shall\r","Now seeming sweet convert to bitter gall.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","\r","JULIET:\r","Good pilgrim, you do wrong your hand too much,\r","Which mannerly devotion shows in this;\r","For saints have hands that pilgrims' hands do touch,\r","And palm to palm is holy palmers' kiss.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Have not saints lips, and holy palmers too?\r","\r","JULIET:\r","Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","O, then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do;\r","They pray, grant thou, lest faith turn to despair.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","Saints do not move, though grant for prayers' sake.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Then move not, while my prayer's effect I take.\r","Thus from my lips, by yours, my sin is purged.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","Then have my lips the sin that they have took.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Sin from thy lips? O trespass sweetly urged!\r","Give me my sin again.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","You kiss by the book.\r","\r","Nurse:\r","Madam, your mother craves a word with you.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","What is her mother?\r","\r","Nurse:\r","Marry, bachelor,\r","Her mother is the lady of the house,\r","And a good lady, and a wise and virtuous\r","I nursed her daughter, that you talk'd withal;\r","I tell you, he that can lay hold of her\r","Shall have the chinks.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Is she a Capulet?\r","O dear account! my life is my foe's debt.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","Away, begone; the sport is at the best.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Ay, so I fear; the more is my unrest.\r","\r","CAPULET:\r","Nay, gentlemen, prepare not to be gone;\r","We have a trifling foolish banquet towards.\r","Is it e'en so? why, then, I thank you all\r","I thank you, honest gentlemen; good night.\r","More torches here! Come on then, let's to bed.\r","Ah, sirrah, by my fay, it waxes late:\r","I'll to my rest.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","Come hither, nurse. What is yond gentleman?\r","\r","Nurse:\r","The son and heir of old Tiberio.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","What's he that now is going out of door?\r","\r","Nurse:\r","Marry, that, I think, be young Petrucio.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","What's he that follows there, that would not dance?\r","\r","Nurse:\r","I know not.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","Go ask his name: if he be married.\r","My grave is like to be my wedding bed.\r","\r","Nurse:\r","His name is Romeo, and a Montague;\r","The only son of your great enemy.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","My only love sprung from my only hate!\r","Too early seen unknown, and known too late!\r","Prodigious birth of love it is to me,\r","That I must love a loathed enemy.\r","\r","Nurse:\r","What's this? what's this?\r","\r","JULIET:\r","A rhyme I learn'd even now\r","Of one I danced withal.\r","\r","Nurse:\r","Anon, anon!\r","Come, let's away; the strangers all are gone.\r","\r","Chorus:\r","Now old desire doth in his death-bed lie,\r","And young affection gapes to be his heir;\r","That fair for which love groan'd for and would die,\r","With tender Juliet match'd, is now not fair.\r","Now Romeo is beloved and loves again,\r","Alike betwitched by the charm of looks,\r","But to his foe supposed he must complain,\r","And she steal love's sweet bait from fearful hooks:\r","Being held a foe, he may not have access\r","To breathe such vows as lovers use to swear;\r","And she as much in love, her means much less\r","To meet her new-beloved any where:\r","But passion lends them power, time means, to meet\r","Tempering extremities with extreme sweet.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Can I go forward when my heart is here?\r","Turn back, dull earth, and find thy centre out.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","Romeo! my cousin Romeo!\r","\r","MERCUTIO:\r","He is wise;\r","And, on my lie, hath stol'n him home to bed.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","He ran this way, and leap'd this orchard wall:\r","Call, good Mercutio.\r","\r","MERCUTIO:\r","Nay, I'll conjure too.\r","Romeo! humours! madman! passion! lover!\r","Appear thou in the likeness of a sigh:\r","Speak but one rhyme, and I am satisfied;\r","Cry but 'Ay me!' pronounce but 'love' and 'dove;'\r","Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word,\r","One nick-name for her purblind son and heir,\r","Young Adam Cupid, he that shot so trim,\r","When King Cophetua loved the beggar-maid!\r","He heareth not, he stirreth not, he moveth not;\r","The ape is dead, and I must conjure him.\r","I conjure thee by Rosaline's bright eyes,\r","By her high forehead and her scarlet lip,\r","By her fine foot, straight leg and quivering thigh\r","And the demesnes that there adjacent lie,\r","That in thy likeness thou appear to us!\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","And if he hear thee, thou wilt anger him.\r","\r","MERCUTIO:\r","This cannot anger him: 'twould anger him\r","To raise a spirit in his mistress' circle\r","Of some strange nature, letting it there stand\r","Till she had laid it and conjured it down;\r","That were some spite: my invocation\r","Is fair and honest, and in his mistress' name\r","I conjure only but to raise up him.\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","Come, he hath hid himself among these trees,\r","To be consorted with the humorous night:\r","Blind is his love and best befits the dark.\r","\r","MERCUTIO:\r","If love be blind, love cannot hit the mark.\r","Now will he sit under a medlar tree,\r","And wish his mistress were that kind of fruit\r","As maids call medlars, when they laugh alone.\r","Romeo, that she were, O, that she were\r","An open et caetera, thou a poperin pear!\r","Romeo, good night: I'll to my truckle-bed;\r","This field-bed is too cold for me to sleep:\r","Come, shall we go?\r","\r","BENVOLIO:\r","Go, then; for 'tis in vain\r","To seek him here that means not to be found.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","He jests at scars that never felt a wound.\r","But, soft! what light through yonder window breaks?\r","It is the east, and Juliet is the sun.\r","Arise, fair sun, and kill the envious moon,\r","Who is already sick and pale with grief,\r","That thou her maid art far more fair than she:\r","Be not her maid, since she is envious;\r","Her vestal livery is but sick and green\r","And none but fools do wear it; cast it off.\r","It is my lady, O, it is my love!\r","O, that she knew she were!\r","She speaks yet she says nothing: what of that?\r","Her eye discourses; I will answer it.\r","I am too bold, 'tis not to me she speaks:\r","Two of the fairest stars in all the heaven,\r","Having some business, do entreat her eyes\r","To twinkle in their spheres till they return.\r","What if her eyes were there, they in her head?\r","The brightness of her cheek would shame those stars,\r","As daylight doth a lamp; her eyes in heaven\r","Would through the airy region stream so bright\r","That birds would sing and think it were not night.\r","See, how she leans her cheek upon her hand!\r","O, that I were a glove upon that hand,\r","That I might touch that cheek!\r","\r","JULIET:\r","Ay me!\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","She speaks:\r","O, speak again, bright angel! for thou art\r","As glorious to this night, being o'er my head\r","As is a winged messenger of heaven\r","Unto the white-upturned wondering eyes\r","Of mortals that fall back to gaze on him\r","When he bestrides the lazy-pacing clouds\r","And sails upon the bosom of the air.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","O Romeo, Romeo! wherefore art thou Romeo?\r","Deny thy father and refuse thy name;\r","Or, if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love,\r","And I'll no longer be a Capulet.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","\r","JULIET:\r","'Tis but thy name that is my enemy;\r","Thou art thyself, though not a Montague.\r","What's Montague? it is nor hand, nor foot,\r","Nor arm, nor face, nor any other part\r","Belonging to a man. O, be some other name!\r","What's in a name? that which we call a rose\r","By any other name would smell as sweet;\r","So Romeo would, were he not Romeo call'd,\r","Retain that dear perfection which he owes\r","Without that title. Romeo, doff thy name,\r","And for that name which is no part of thee\r","Take all myself.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","I take thee at thy word:\r","Call me but love, and I'll be new baptized;\r","Henceforth I never will be Romeo.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","What man art thou that thus bescreen'd in night\r","So stumblest on my counsel?\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","By a name\r","I know not how to tell thee who I am:\r","My name, dear saint, is hateful to myself,\r","Because it is an enemy to thee;\r","Had I it written, I would tear the word.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","My ears have not yet drunk a hundred words\r","Of that tongue's utterance, yet I know the sound:\r","Art thou not Romeo and a Montague?\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Neither, fair saint, if either thee dislike.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","How camest thou hither, tell me, and wherefore?\r","The orchard walls are high and hard to climb,\r","And the place death, considering who thou art,\r","If any of my kinsmen find thee here.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","With love's light wings did I o'er-perch these walls;\r","For stony limits cannot hold love out,\r","And what love can do that dares love attempt;\r","Therefore thy kinsmen are no let to me.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","If they do see thee, they will murder thee.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Alack, there lies more peril in thine eye\r","Than twenty of their swords: look thou but sweet,\r","And I am proof against their enmity.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","I would not for the world they saw thee here.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","I have night's cloak to hide me from their sight;\r","And but thou love me, let them find me here:\r","My life were better ended by their hate,\r","Than death prorogued, wanting of thy love.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","By whose direction found'st thou out this place?\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","By love, who first did prompt me to inquire;\r","He lent me counsel and I lent him eyes.\r","I am no pilot; yet, wert thou as far\r","As that vast shore wash'd with the farthest sea,\r","I would adventure for such merchandise.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","Thou know'st the mask of night is on my face,\r","Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek\r","For that which thou hast heard me speak to-night\r","Fain would I dwell on form, fain, fain deny\r","What I have spoke: but farewell compliment!\r","Dost thou love me? I know thou wilt say 'Ay,'\r","And I will take thy word: yet if thou swear'st,\r","Thou mayst prove false; at lovers' perjuries\r","Then say, Jove laughs. O gentle Romeo,\r","If thou dost love, pronounce it faithfully:\r","Or if thou think'st I am too quickly won,\r","I'll frown and be perverse an say thee nay,\r","So thou wilt woo; but else, not for the world.\r","In truth, fair Montague, I am too fond,\r","And therefore thou mayst think my 'havior light:\r","But trust me, gentleman, I'll prove more true\r","Than those that have more cunning to be strange.\r","I should have been more strange, I must confess,\r","But that thou overheard'st, ere I was ware,\r","My true love's passion: therefore pardon me,\r","And not impute this yielding to light love,\r","Which the dark night hath so discovered.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Lady, by yonder blessed moon I swear\r","That tips with silver all these fruit-tree tops--\r","\r","JULIET:\r","O, swear not by the moon, the inconstant moon,\r","That monthly changes in her circled orb,\r","Lest that thy love prove likewise variable.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","What shall I swear by?\r","\r","JULIET:\r","Do not swear at all;\r","Or, if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self,\r","Which is the god of my idolatry,\r","And I'll believe thee.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","If my heart's dear love--\r","\r","JULIET:\r","Well, do not swear: although I joy in thee,\r","I have no joy of this contract to-night:\r","It is too rash, too unadvised, too sudden;\r","Too like the lightning, which doth cease to be\r","Ere one can say 'It lightens.' Sweet, good night!\r","This bud of love, by summer's ripening breath,\r","May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet.\r","Good night, good night! as sweet repose and rest\r","Come to thy heart as that within my breast!\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","O, wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?\r","\r","JULIET:\r","What satisfaction canst thou have to-night?\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","The exchange of thy love's faithful vow for mine.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","I gave thee mine before thou didst request it:\r","And yet I would it were to give again.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Wouldst thou withdraw it? for what purpose, love?\r","\r","JULIET:\r","But to be frank, and give it thee again.\r","And yet I wish but for the thing I have:\r","My bounty is as boundless as the sea,\r","My love as deep; the more I give to thee,\r","The more I have, for both are infinite.\r","I hear some noise within; dear love, adieu!\r","Anon, good nurse! Sweet Montague, be true.\r","Stay but a little, I will come again.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","O blessed, blessed night! I am afeard.\r","Being in night, all this is but a dream,\r","Too flattering-sweet to be substantial.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.\r","If that thy bent of love be honourable,\r","Thy purpose marriage, send me word to-morrow,\r","By one that I'll procure to come to thee,\r","Where and what time thou wilt perform the rite;\r","And all my fortunes at thy foot I'll lay\r","And follow thee my lord throughout the world.\r","\r","Nurse:\r","\r","JULIET:\r","I come, anon.--But if thou mean'st not well,\r","I do beseech thee--\r","\r","Nurse:\r","\r","JULIET:\r","By and by, I come:--\r","To cease thy suit, and leave me to my grief:\r","To-morrow will I send.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","So thrive my soul--\r","\r","JULIET:\r","A thousand times good night!\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","A thousand times the worse, to want thy light.\r","Love goes toward love, as schoolboys from\r","their books,\r","But love from love, toward school with heavy looks.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","Hist! Romeo, hist! O, for a falconer's voice,\r","To lure this tassel-gentle back again!\r","Bondage is hoarse, and may not speak aloud;\r","Else would I tear the cave where Echo lies,\r","And make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine,\r","With repetition of my Romeo's name.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","It is my soul that calls upon my name:\r","How silver-sweet sound lovers' tongues by night,\r","Like softest music to attending ears!\r","\r","JULIET:\r","Romeo!\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","My dear?\r","\r","JULIET:\r","At what o'clock to-morrow\r","Shall I send to thee?\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","At the hour of nine.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","I will not fail: 'tis twenty years till then.\r","I have forgot why I did call thee back.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Let me stand here till thou remember it.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","I shall forget, to have thee still stand there,\r","Remembering how I love thy company.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","And I'll still stay, to have thee still forget,\r","Forgetting any other home but this.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","'Tis almost morning; I would have thee gone:\r","And yet no further than a wanton's bird;\r","Who lets it hop a little from her hand,\r","Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves,\r","And with a silk thread plucks it back again,\r","So loving-jealous of his liberty.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","I would I were thy bird.\r","\r","JULIET:\r","Sweet, so would I:\r","Yet I should kill thee with much cherishing.\r","Good night, good night! parting is such\r","sweet sorrow,\r","That I shall say good night till it be morrow.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Sleep dwell upon thine eyes, peace in thy breast!\r","Would I were sleep and peace, so sweet to rest!\r","Hence will I to my ghostly father's cell,\r","His help to crave, and my dear hap to tell.\r","\r","FRIAR LAURENCE:\r","The grey-eyed morn smiles on the frowning night,\r","Chequering the eastern clouds with streaks of light,\r","And flecked darkness like a drunkard reels\r","From forth day's path and Titan's fiery wheels:\r","Now, ere the sun advance his burning eye,\r","The day to cheer and night's dank dew to dry,\r","I must up-fill this osier cage of ours\r","With baleful weeds and precious-juiced flowers.\r","The earth that's nature's mother is her tomb;\r","What is her burying grave that is her womb,\r","And from her womb children of divers kind\r","We sucking on her natural bosom find,\r","Many for many virtues excellent,\r","None but for some and yet all different.\r","O, mickle is the powerful grace that lies\r","In herbs, plants, stones, and their true qualities:\r","For nought so vile that on the earth doth live\r","But to the earth some special good doth give,\r","Nor aught so good but strain'd from that fair use\r","Revolts from true birth, stumbling on abuse:\r","Virtue itself turns vice, being misapplied;\r","And vice sometimes by action dignified.\r","Within the infant rind of this small flower\r","Poison hath residence and medicine power:\r","For this, being smelt, with that part cheers each part;\r","Being tasted, slays all senses with the heart.\r","Two such opposed kings encamp them still\r","In man as well as herbs, grace and rude will;\r","And where the worser is predominant,\r","Full soon the canker death eats up that plant.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Good morrow, father.\r","\r","FRIAR LAURENCE:\r","Benedicite!\r","What early tongue so sweet saluteth me?\r","Young son, it argues a distemper'd head\r","So soon to bid good morrow to thy bed:\r","Care keeps his watch in every old man's eye,\r","And where care lodges, sleep will never lie;\r","But where unbruised youth with unstuff'd brain\r","Doth couch his limbs, there golden sleep doth reign:\r","Therefore thy earliness doth me assure\r","Thou art up-roused by some distemperature;\r","Or if not so, then here I hit it right,\r","Our Romeo hath not been in bed to-night.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","That last is true; the sweeter rest was mine.\r","\r","FRIAR LAURENCE:\r","God pardon sin! wast thou with Rosaline?\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","With Rosaline, my ghostly father? no;\r","I have forgot that name, and that name's woe.\r","\r","FRIAR LAURENCE:\r","That's my good son: but where hast thou been, then?\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","I'll tell thee, ere thou ask it me again.\r","I have been feasting with mine enemy,\r","Where on a sudden one hath wounded me,\r","That's by me wounded: both our remedies\r","Within thy help and holy physic lies:\r","I bear no hatred, blessed man, for, lo,\r","My intercession likewise steads my foe.\r","\r","FRIAR LAURENCE:\r","Be plain, good son, and homely in thy drift;\r","Riddling confession finds but riddling shrift.\r","\r","ROMEO:\r","Then plainly know my heart's dear love is set\r","On the fair daughter of rich Capulet:\r","As mine on hers, so hers is set on mine;\r","And all combined, save what thou must combine\r","By holy marriage: when and where and how\r","We met, we woo'd and made exchange of vow,\r","I'll tell thee as we pass; but this I pray,\r","That thou consent to marry us to-day.\r","\r","FRIAR LAURENCE:\r","Holy Saint Francis, what a change is here!\r","Is Rosaline, whom thou didst love so dear,\r","So soon forsaken? young men's love then lies\r","Not truly in their hearts, but in their eyes.\r","Jesu Maria, what a deal of brine\r","Hath wash'd thy sallow cheeks for Rosaline!\r","How much salt water thrown away in
